description: All you need to know is .. Pad See Eww with Shrimp! Ba da bing! Ba da BOOM!
author: Mason T.

description:
I love Thai food, and every time I come here it totally hits the spot.  There are only 3 things I want to eat when I'm up late and intoxicated.  Pizza, Jack in the Box, or THAI FOOD!  This place usually wins.

I only order 2 things.  Either the Pad See Ew, or the Bonless Chicken.  I wish I could review their Pad thai for you but... I'm allergic to peanuts!!! Sorry... but, I know people love Pad See Ew so definitely check this place out.  

They also give you tons of food!!!  Unless you are a big eater, you just got yourself dinner and lunch for tomorrow!

Recap:

Great Food
Open Late
Big Portions
author: Andrew G.

description:
I always look forward to dining at this King of Thai...
1) after a performance at the Palace of Fine Arts
2) when I find myself on Clement St and don't feel like waiting at the madhouse that is Burma Superstar
3) we want something fast and inexpensive
4) we've got something like 40 or so odd souls with us and need a place that can accomodate

...and that's King of Thai on Clement -- at around 10pm on a Sunday night, they were able to gracefully seat and serve a host of some 40(!) dancers who had streamed out of of Palace of Fine Arts San Francisco Hip Hop Dance Festival and were prowling and ravenous.

I have to admit my own small group arrived a smidge early, and so while others were still milling about outside and pressing their noses against the glass much like the zombies in 'Shaun of the Dead' (will they seat us? they look scared..) we got our food in lickety-split time.

I always order their Ped Yang rice dish -- a heaping plate of boneless roast duck served over yau choy greens, rice and accompanied with a sweetish soy sauce.  The boy usually chooses one of their stir-fried seafood noodle dishes or their fried rice dishes.  The portions are so generous we often have leftovers to take home.

By the time we had finished our own meals, all the other dancers were seated and happily digging into their dinners as well.  Bravo, King of Thai! O, you are magnificent!
author: Claudine C.

description:
I like the food, but I also dislike this place--apparently the food makes me sick sometimes. I think my stomach just can't handle spicy foods. 

The GF ordered a pineapple fried rice and I ordered a noodle dish. I love both dishes because they are extremely flavor. That also means there must be a lot of salt in them + the food drips with grease. That being said, we try to limit our visits to King of Thai for health reasons.
author: Nathan E.

description: Pad Thai was on the sweet side. Tofu cubes were very hard, probably not too fresh? Shrimp was good. Reasonble price and portion.
author: Vivian W.

description: I'm usually weary of favoriting chain restaurants but I figured I like McDonalds so why not King of Thai? It's a small KOT in the Richmond, but they run a tight ship. They're pretty quick, even during peak hours. I typically call in for take out, and they usually make me wait longer than the sit down customers, but it's still convenient for me.  Food is pretty well flavored, maybe a bit on the oilier or saltier side for some, but I like it. I'm tempted to try out the KOT 2 that's also on Clement just for comparison, but never have yet.
author: K C.

description:
Although I've only checked in here a few times, my actual attendance count is somewhere in the twenties. The food is amazing. If you like Chicken Pad Thai, you'd be very hard pressed to find a better place for it, even in San Francisco. My understanding is that the noodles are made in house, and have the perfect weight, texture, and flavor (oxford comma ftw). Also, everything tastes very fresh and that always impresses me.

I really like the fried tofu dish in addition to the Pad Thai. I don't remember what it's called, but I do remember that not every King of Thai Noodle House has it, so be sure to get it when you're here.

The food also keeps really well overnight and makes a great leftover meal. Which is a good thing because the dishes are all fairly large, especially for the price. I can usually spend less than 10 bucks after tip.
author: Doug B.

description:
Stumbled in here after a long recon mission to CitiKids, starving, and was in no way disappointed. The green papaya salad, which I shared with my date, was pungent, flavorful, and just spicy enough to make me cough after my first bite. Pumpkin curry with prawns followed -- sweet, creamy and just spicy enough, with lots and lots of prawns. It could have used a little more squash, given its name, but I left feeling full and happy nonetheless. Yum. 

My date had one of the noodle soups and said it was good, if a bit bland. But then, he added extra chilies to his papaya salad, so his tastes are calibrated a bit differently from mine.
author: Beth W.

description:
Gotta love their padthai and the beef stew boat noodle here.
Food = 4 stars
service = 2 1/5 stars
author: Alternate N.

description:
King of Thai Noodle rocks!!
they are THE BEST!!

5 stars for your wonderful food--from the Pad Thai, to the Crab Fried Rice, to the red, yellow, green curry, the stir friend vermicelli noodles, to their Thai milk tea--they make all of it perfect

IT TASTES THE WAY IT IS SUPPOSED TO!!

you have to try the Larb--it's a cabbage salad w/ beef & basil, seasoned with lime. 

the deco is not all that great, and they are not the cleanest place in town (i wouldn't lick the table if i were you)

their food is good, it comes very fast, they are open late, the portions are good, and the price is cheap
solid five stars
author: Wei L.

description:
I usually go to King of Thai for their Spicy Noodle Soup. So this review is based on that particular item. 

I remember this use to be the best place of all the King of Thai locations. I just went here tonight and tried their #4 Spicy Beef Noodle Soup. It was okay, wasn't great or bad. It does taste a little different from the Taraval + Sloat. The soup was just a little spicier, and leaves a tingly note after you sip it. Instead of giving spinach in the soup, this place actually give you "oong choy". Oong choy was the oringinal vegetable that was in their spicy beef soup, but many place has cheap out and replaced it with other cheap vegetables. 

Just a couple cents more, but it's still worth it. High recommend.
author: MT D.

description: First, off, this place has hands down the best tom yum/tom goong soup I've ever experienced! It's spicy with fresh ingredients and just the right mix of flavors. (Many Thai places in the U.S. do more "Americanized" versions of tom yum, but this is authentically Thai.) They also have excellent pad thai. I would give maybe 3.5-4 stars to the more beef broth/gravy dishes I sampled, though. They have very quick service and convenient late hours.
author: Kelly W.

description:
I was visiting my friend and this place caught my eye as we walked down Clement Street. Whenever I see a Thai restaurant, my eyes always get bigger.

Let's just say I liked this place so much I came two days in a row during my five-day visit with her. I wanted to make it THREE days, but we had other places we had to try. I only wish I remembered exactly what I ordered. It was like Pad Kee Mao, but I remember the noodles were spaghetti noodles. I also got something similar to Kra Pow and got it with tofu. It was awesome.

The only bad things are it's cash only and the wait can be a while, but I say it's worth it. The prices are fairly decent, the portions huge, and it is open late.
author: Emily C.

description: I'd say best in SF. I have been here many times without a bad meal. I took my Hmong friends, and they are very picky, but they said they enjoyed this place!! Also the neighborhood has a lot to offer, within walking distance. The Aquarium-flower shop is dope!
author: Anthony C.

description:
The cheesy name and ugly bright purple sign add to the experience at King of Thai Noodle. 

Food - above average
Service - below average
Prices - as they should be...cheap.

I'd go here again with people who appreciate a whole in the wall.
author: Mike D.

description:
Good, cheap Thai food. Almost like the street food in Bangkok. This is a dependable joint for those evenings when we just can't think of what to cook. Bleh, no more frozen Trader Joe's meals! 

If you want no nonsense Thai food this is it. It's still 3-4x more than the street food in Thailand but then again rent here is also that much more in SF. And if you're ever eating here during the NBA playoffs or finals they will be showing them so you can watch the game while ignoring your date. Just blame the spicy food for the lack of conversation.
author: C L.

description: don't count on getting your food if you order delivery. we waited an hour and a half for our order, after which we decided to call and see what the deal was, only to be informed that we were out of their delivery area. no apology, no offer to still deliver us food. keep in mind we are a mile and a half from their restaurant. really wanted to give this place a try after reading all the great reviews, but after this fiasco, can't really see myself giving them my business. big thumbs down and many crying emojis.
author: Laurent T.

description: Food here is tasty, warm and just overall good.
author: Alan L.

description:
This little (inexpensive) GEM is a must when seeking a causal and devine meal in the city. It has an extremely unassuming exterior as well as a very basic interior, but that's where the basics end.  The food here is so good it's hard for me to find words... orgasmic? You'll be moaning and groaning at every bite... MMMmmmm ahhh mmMMM! I always have the Gang Graree (yellow curry) with chicken $6.25 and the Cashew Chicken (I think it is called Gal Pad Med Mamuang, however I always just ask for the Cashew Chicken). They're both fall-off-the-chair good.

If at all possible, I dine here every time I come to San Francisco.
author: L.B. K.

description: This is my go to place for Thai food now. The food is delicious, service is quick, price is cheap, and the best thing is that they're open till 1:30 am. Really what else could you ask for? I can't recommend this place more!
author: Vincent W.

description: My husband and I love King of Thai! It's our go to place for late night dinning. Try the peanut sauce you will not regret it. Then hit up Genki a few doors down for a crepe!
author: Bobby B.

description:
I like King of Thai... until they SHRANK my food, by HALF !!!!

I went  to the King of Thai on clement near 7th Ave (the tiny one) and wanted to grab a quick dinner before work. The waitresses paid no attention to me and my friend -- two of them were too busy to take order from the SAME table with only one person there.

I ordered my usual Pad Thai and when the food came, my friend and I were shocked -- it was HALF the size as before. I worked out before dinner but that shouldn't affect the perception of the size of Pad Thai of both my friend and I. Was the cook too hungry and ate half of my Pad Thai?

Service was not good either -- they paid all their attention on the kids on the table nearby ; I mean, they don't need to have 2 waitresses serving/playing with 1 adult and 2 kids?

It is a COMPLETELY UNPLEASANT experience in King of Thai. 
Same Price but Half the food? No way, no more King of Thai for me. It's just ridiculous.
author: Doris H.

description:
My no. 1 delivery option! They are so fast, and consistently delicious. I have yet to try something that I don't like here - if you are a newbie, I would suggest the Red Curry Dish (Gang Panang), or even just their fried rice (Kao Pad) - the best I've had in my life. 

This is also the best place to go for late-night eats. I believe they're open until 1:30 pm, so they make a perfect ending to a crazy night out.
author: Sarah H.

description: I must give praise--this restaurant made me loove pad-see-ew!  This was the first place I tried it (years and years ago) and it is sooo good!!  I actually prefer this to the more commonly ordered pad thai.  When I was away at school, home visits to the bay required a stop here to get some of my favorite dish.  One time I was even craving it late at night (and I'm not sure if it's still the case) but this location happened to be open late so that was no problem at all!
author: Tess E.

description: One of my all time favorite go to restaurants in sf. I can't seem to stop ordering the Pumpkin Curry and Pad Thai....so yum! a Fresh, delicious dinner for two for around $20? Amazing!!
author: Neil W.

description:
Good Thai food with decent portions
Opens Late just in case if you're drunk and hungry
Cute and friendly Waitress
Fighting for a parking space with a bunch of Chinese people is a bitch, unless you're going there @ 1AM

OneLiner: Great place to go and get food and served by cute Thai girls @ 1AM
author: Yummy P.

description:
Oh, gross man. 

I drifted in here on a weekend after hitting the area watering holes and, had I not been wildly drunk, I think I would have been pissed. 

You really have to be intoxicated or in good company to feel content here. The place is filled with diner style tables and the servers are mechanical and always seem overwhelmed.

I got the fried fish appetizer thing, which was ok but made me feel a little sick afterward. I got the yellow curry and i might as well have ordered a bowl of soup. 

This is the Mels or the Lucky penny of thai food. You get more attention at even best of thai on haight.
author: Jay C.

description:
The pad thai here is delicious.  I used to go to pub quiz down the street, and this was the perfect nightcap to my long night.

Minor complaint, though.  Some guy and ordered the same dish, so the chef made two portions in the same wok.  He dumped around 2/3 of the contents of the wok into one container, causing it to overflow ... and the remaining less than 1/3 of the wok into another container, leaving it more than half empty.  

The guy doing the bagging of the food noticed this discrepancy and said something to the chef who shook his hand at the guy and started preparing another order, ignoring the man's questioning look.  

Guess who got shafted and was handed the half empty container?  I pulled the container out of the bag, opened it and asked the guy at the register if HE would pay $7.50 for a half filled container of bean sprouts and one shrimp.  He said no, headed to the chef who then proceeded to dump it in a wok and add more bean sprouts to it.  I left with a  half-filled container of bean sprouts and a lonely little shrimp.

Mean, mean chef.  I was so starved that night!!  :(
author: Jenny K.

description:
I don't know much about Thai food but when its 2 in the a.m. and im burnt the first thing that comes to mind is how the hell am I gonna get home. Then I think of King of Thai.

Like I said, I'm Thai food ignorant so i consider this to be actual Thai food.  I have a friend who disses King of Thai all day cause she says it's not "genuine" Thai food. She's Thai by the way.  
The food is VERY reasonably priced and your food is ready in about 3 - 5 minutes.  The service is decently friendly, but hey, your paying about $7 for a filling meal that'll make it to your table before your drinks do. #31 and #15 is what puts an end to my night. I'm not gonna bother to pronounce what 31 and 15 are.

My only beef is that it is CASH ONLY and the late-night parking can be a bit of a hassle. Other than that, if your sick of the bad-service nastiness called Denny's, take a trip out to King of Thai.
author: Kyle E.

description:
When I need comfort food (which for me is either Thai, Indian or middle eastern) I don't expect frills, or good service for that matter.  I want my food good and cheap, and perhaps even a little oily.  

As a result, I have found myself at King of Thai on many nights (followed by a crepe at Genki). Their Pad Kee Mao is solid (although for the rice noodle dishes, be sure to ask for you meat in chunks, or else you'll end up disappointed with an entire dish of noodles with itty bitty bits of mean mixed in).  The kee mao is a little lacking on the vegetables, usually just green beans, but it does the job.  Also their fried bananas and coconut ice cream are yum too.
author: Jasmine B.

description:
I liked the Pad Thai. For $7, the portion was right. Not big, but big enough to keep me full without feeling any adverse side-effects.

Small place though. I don't enjoy eating while sitting next to people within arm's length.
author: Justin L.

description:
Best Thai food I've had yet.  I usually order #21, been doing that for years, since I first went there in '95.  LOL I still don't know the name of the item, but its basically ground meat (I usually get the chicken) with basil and a sweet sauce, garnished with bell peppers, and over rice. Very tasty, and even better with an over easy egg on top.

The Pineapple fried rice, satay chicken, and pad thai is all very tasty as well.

Have to say the portions are pretty big for the amount you pay, and the  service is fast. 

Whenever I'm in SF late night and want great food for very reasonable prices, I go there.
author: Janeiro M.

description:
There is something so wonderful in the simplicity of King of Thai's #37 that has enamored me since I put that fried chicken in my mouth my senior year in HS at Lakeshore Plaza.  Being from the city, each San Franciscan has at least three fail-safe, surefire places to eat aside from fast food...(mines being Gordos, Americana, King of Thai)  The presentation is very simple:
1.  fried rice
2.  cucumbers
3.  egg
4.  fried chicken breast
5.  tomato slices
6.  their sweet and sour sauce
It is ironic that a dish that contains only 6 ingredients is often imitated yet has not once been duplicated.  Sure you have more expensive Thai food places out there but none will ever achieve the cult classic status King of Thai has, especially in the hearts of pubescent middle/high schoolers.  The tradition behind King of Thai is rich as it is hearty.  The flaky batter surrounding the chicken breast, dampened by the dousing of sauce followed by a melodramatic sigh is an emotion synonymous with San Francisco.  It is literally  iconic.  You have the rustic Golden Gate Bridge, then you have.....King of Thai on Clement and in every other district.  You cannot escape it.

invaluable note: If you are on a date with a high maintenance broad and want to eat King of Thai, yet still want to impress your date, there is a King of Thai premium next to the House in North Beach.  The lighting is dim and seductive, menus laminated, waitresses dainty, the bartenders minxes.  Many elder men escape the clutches of their wives for a couple hours to sit by this bar and use 1960's pickup lines.  It is nice to see manners are still around as the bartenders/waitresses politely cover their mouth and tee hee.  I guess this is a sufficient price to pay to receive holy hell when they return home.  The prices are a couple dollars more expensive due to the ambiance, but the point is you can still enjoy a #37 without anyone being the wiser.
author: Brian V.

description:
This is by far my favorite king of thai noodle house in the city.  I love that they are a hole in the wall, because it keeps the prices down.  The waitresses are very friendly (and definitely not eyesores).  Quick service, excellent food.

You can't go wrong with the pad see ew.
author: Jenny L.

description:
the crab fried rice with chicken and the beef pad see-ew was exceptionally bomb.
its a super chill spot where the servers (both men and women) wear purple t-shirts (exceptionally uncool imho) 
BUT the service was fast and helpful.

my new favorite spot!
author: Bee B.

description: The worst place on earth, if you ask me, I ordered a Soup and a coffee, both terrible. Let's not mention my meal came 10 min later than my friend's and when we dared to ask the server about it, he disregarded us with a hand motion, told us it will be out soon.
author: Kinga M.

description:
Awesome late night eats... when you need some good Thai noodle dishes this is the best.

personal favorite: Pad Kee Mao
author: Alex P.

description:
this is a no non-sense type of restaurant. you walk in, you sit, you eat, you pay and get out. basically in a nutshell, that's exactly what we did. after a day of partying, my two girlfriends and i went here for dinner. 

i ordered their roasted duck red curry over nice and it was so tasty! the prices were reasonable and this narrow restaurant only seats 32 people. by the time we left, there was a long line out the door. i've been to the king of thai noodle house in NoBe and it's not like that place at all because their kitchen is pretty open, seats are located in the back and the back door is their unisex restroom. (make sure it's locked when in use)

i'd come back here again if i'm ever in the area!
author: Mika D.

description:
Food served very quickly and prices are reasonable / cheap. The portions are small, if compared to typical fast-food Asian restaurants, but just right for me. The taste is also not that bad...but nothing spectacular. The service is mediocre, but didn't expect more than that. The dish I ordered didn't come out looking like what the menu described it as - it was missing cilantro, cucumbers, cashews, and basically any form of veggies. 

Bottom line...it's a A-OK restaurant: good for late night hunger pangs, hangover food runs, place to chill at when everything else is closed, and when you're trying to save a little money.
author: April Z.

description: This is the worse King of Thai Noodles that I've been to. I like lime, and the noodle I ordered comes with lime. Their lime had 1 drop of juice in it. I asked for another lime, another 1 drop. I asked for a lime that's more "juicy," they ended up giving me one small plate with limes. Each wedge this time had plentiful of juices and was enough to finally go around w/ all my friends. The bill comes, blam, $3 charge for a small plate of lime? Give me a &*$%ing break.
author: Calvin D.

description: Come on. It's King of Thai. It's everywhere. It opens til the wee hours of the night. It's cheap. There's decent food and thai iced tea. What else can you ask for? :)
author: Wendy L.

description: This place is "Bomb". I remember passing it up and saying "Ohhh That place is next on my list of restaurants to try."  Now I regret taking so damn looooong to try it. Now..., You can't get me out of this place, Haha. I love their noodles, fried chicken over fried rice...Yum! If you have your last 10.00 in your pocket and hungry. Go here! You won't be disappointed
author: Carla F.

description: Being fairly close to USF, I used to go here all the time. I would always order the Pad See Ew with chicken; however, over the past months I've noticed the inconsistent quality of the food. On some days it tastes fresh and delicious, and on others stale and microwaved. The food alone would have gotten 3 stars, but to add that to the poor customer service leaves this Noodle House with a generous 1 star.
author: Niki J.

description: Best pumpkin I have had and everyone's food looked fresh and tasty. Great portions and I dig on the layout. Kitchen up front and eat in the back. Prices are fair and food is fast.
author: William R.

description: Affordable and quality of food is great.  Portion sizes are good too.  Inside, the place looks old and dingy, with the bathroom placed very near where customers are eating.  But overall, if you just want some tasty thai eats, this hole in the wall locale should be your go-to thai restaurant.  Fast service too!
author: Reeni P.

description:
Tell me why the original is always the best?

For some reason no matter which of the other King of Thai's I visit, none of them compare to this one. The sauces and soups just taste that little bit better here. Nothing else quite hits the spot for cheap thai food in the richmond.
author: Torie Y.

description:
This is my go-to cheap Thai restaurant.

Things I like:
 - it's open late!
 - good quality, cheap Thai food
 - fast service, espcially if you walk in and order take-out

Things I don't like:
 - depending on time of day, parking can be a problem
 - once there was a large amount of egg shell in my noodle dish (out of maybe 50 visits over the past few years)
author: kiki d.

description: portions are big.  service is fast.  they dont charge for hot tea.  some of the fish cakes tasted a bit off. overall not bad. but not great.
author: claudia y.

description: The hype is real!  Praised pretty widely, I had my first brush with King of Thai Noodle house and was impressed by all the dishes I tried (pad kee mow, pad see ew, and fried rice).  Nicely flavored without any msg dry mouth experience afterwards, I'd pick this over Osha any day of the week, as I feel that you pay for the ambiance and location, rather than quality of food.
author: Jeff N.

description: Delicious spicy thai stir fry dishes at a cheap price .. what more can you want?
author: Janice M.

description: This is my favorite place to wrap up a night out.  I always order the soup noodles, and I haven't had one I didn't like.
author: Katharine N.

description:
Cheap. Decent. Thai food. 

That's about this place in a nutshell. It's bare bones, quick and you can walk out the door with a heaping pile of Thai noodles without breaking the $8 mark. Best for take-out.
author: Brandon B.

description:
Wow how did I not see this place before on Clement? Tried our luck for a late late dinner on Clement, not sure if any places were open past midnight. Bf and I ducked in here not expecting much, just glad we didn't have to go to always-disappointing Mel's Diner on Geary. 

I ordered noodle soup w/ roast duck and bf ordered some thick noodley dish w/ green peppers and some delicious meat on top (sorry, the details are a bit hazy). Everything was surprisingly tasty and satisfying. Service was prompt. And I got to watch Sex and the City while dining. Fashion, drama and food, gotta love it.

This is a great little place that doesn't disappoint. I think this is our new "standby" restaurant when we don't know what to eat.
author: Jen P.

description: I love this King of Thai. I've eaten at 3 locations here in sf and this one is by far the best. (the north beach location is the worst food-wise) It's also probably the smallest location so I recommend doing take out or delivery. The service is super fast and the staff is nice Most definitely recommend the pad kee mao, pad see ew, pineapple, fried rice, pad thai ahhh i am getting hungry just thinking about it. I think all of the dishes are between $8-$10 so super cheap. It's also open until 2am so great option on those late nights!
author: Ally L.

description:
Very very good thai food! Went here last night for the first time and found the atmosphere comfortable, the food delicious and the service ok. The bump bump dance music gave them minus a star. Otherwise, the food was legit and huge portions for sharing tallied our tab to be only $27 by the end of the night. What did that include you may wonder? Well, for starters the crispy spring rolls, then on to the beef ball soup with thin rice noodles and a noodle dish (damn me I forgot the name of it and no it wasn't the Pad Thai). Let's not forget the beer as a thirst quencher. 

One pet peeve I have for the place is the silly paper napkins. Seriously? I mean, everything else in here is so perfect for the place, and ya'll have paper napkins to top off the table? Just wrong.
author: Stephanie J.

description:
Super fast, really tasty, cheap... the Pra Ram is great, as is the Pad See Yu.

No bread, no lemons. Lots of peanuts.

Bread rating: 0
Anti-Scurvy rating: 2 (there was some spinach in the Pra Ram, which does fight scurvy...)
author: Alan B.

description:
Small cozy place.  Be prepared to smell like food when you leave.  They used to be much better (years ago) when the owner lady made the food herself & before they painted the place purple/pink in the inside.

Nonetheless, it's a 4-star for the quality of food, hours and price. 

My fav: Pad See Lew (pan fried noodles with choice of meat/seafood/tofu).  The minced meat with basil over rice is also excellent - get the friend egg for an extra $1.50.

Best Part: Good Thai food past midnight!
author: Bessie T.

description:
The first thing I've ordered at this place was Penang red curry with chicken.  I love the curry sauce and the chicken.  I normally get this take out because there is always enough curry sauce where I could make another serving of rice at home and pour the sauce to make another meal.

I went here with my girlfriend one night to dine in.  She ordered a stir fry beef noodle (it almost looks like the Chinese beef chow fun with basil leaves).  I ordered the garlic basil chicken.  I wasn't that impress with these two dishes.  I have to admit, I've had better garlic basil chicken.

4 stars for the curry
2 stars for the other dishes I've tried.

I'll still come back and get my curry.  Maybe I'll try something else when I'm feeling some Thai but not curry mood.
author: Tim L.

description:
I came here recently with my college buddy and his baby. It wasn't too busy so they gave us a corner table so we had extra room for the stroller. That was nice.

I like Thai curries. Especially the red curry, because it's just a bit spicy.  But I like red curry with duck the most.  They don't offer duck with red curry here.

That automatically means that this place only gets 3 stars.  The food is otherwise fine, but without duck curry, it's not worth coming back unless I'm already in the area and craving Thai food, but not duck. Which isn't often.
author: Robert L.

description:
This is a great noodle place. It's fast, cheap, and good. This place is perfect for quick lunches, dinners, or even midnight snacks.

I had the seafood noodles today and it was pretty good. Now, I just have to work my way down that menu.
author: Barney M.

description:
I love King of Thai. All of them. The two on Clement. The one on Jesse and 5th. The one in Union Square. The fancy one in North Beach (fancy King of Thai?) And all the rest. OK, there is one bad one but I forget.

This one is my favorite. Its kind of frumpy. Its super small. But if you want Pad Kee Mao in 5 minutes, this is the place. Fast fast fast. If you want pumpkin curry that actually tastes of pumpkin this is it. If for some reason the universe has conspired to make your order take 6 minutes instead of a nanosecond, they usually give you a cup of hot tea while you wait. A nice touch.

One of the girls who works there also works at Be My Guest, or at least she used to. which adds the whole remember your name thing, of which I am a sucker. She must have a neuron in her brain that permanently associates my phone number with Pad Kee Mao with Chicken and Tofu to go. 

They have this enormous TV set up in the back which is always playing crazy reality TV like "Worlds Greatest Accidents" some crazy TV dating show. Its a great distraction that always cheers me up. I can see why some people might bag on this place for being a dive, but its high on my list.

I love you King of Thai.
author: Zac H.

description: A bunch of people from Kaiser always come to this particular Thai place and actually rave about it. I'm a fan of Thai Stick but I'm always open to try new Thai places, as Thai food is of the gods. This location is nothing fancy. As other's have said, you come in, sit down, eat and leave. It's rather small and not good for groups at all. We had the pad thai, yellow curry and pumpkin curry. The pumpkin curry was my favorite. I'd go back simply for that. I'm only giving this place three stars because I didn't think it was anything spectacular, but the food is still good.
author: Elle L.

description:
I love this restaurant. It is very tasty, reasonable and it's kind of a hole in the wall, which I like! My partner would give it a 4 of 5 stars...The take out portions are def. smaller than the dine-in....Only con: TV is playing - flat screen-- facing the diners...with dumb shows on - MTV..distracting and odd.. Red Curry is delicious, Pad Thai is quite good, Duck Leg soup- my partner says is yummy.....and Papaya salad is tasty...as is the Tom Ka Ghai (sp?)

Enjoy some cheap yummy treats!
author: Bing B.

description:
just got back from there.

order the pad thai, but substituted the shrimp with chicken.
AMAZING!!!!!
i'm not a big fan of tofu but there's was pretty good.

you know it's good food when you don't need to add condiments or any other toppings.
author: Pahneez H.

description: One of the best thai food places I have ever been to.  Their pad thai is very different from the ones I have tried.  Aside from being tasty, the noodle they used is vermicelli so the flavor is quite strong.  Along with this, I also ordered the roasted duck in red curry.  Very interesting, and very delicious.  Definitely worth a try.
author: Jenny L.

description: I don't come here for the decor which is rather sparse.  However, the first King of Thai Noodle on Clement street never lets me down in terms of price, quantity and quality.  Some of my favorites are the pineapple fried rice, chicken rice noodle soup (you can ask for less noodles if you're on the Zone diet), Pad See Ewe (flat noodles with broccoli and egg and sweet black soy sauce) and Pad Plik Khing (long string beans with spicy sauce and a choice of protein).  There are other Thai restaurants which have elaborate menus and such, but I often have difficulty finding Pad Thai Noodles which include BOTH shrimp and tofu.  Most places nowadays will only give you shrimp or tofu. I also like to order the hot Thai tea with no cream (I'm lactose intolerant) instead of Thai iced tea.
author: Bodhi D.

description:
Inexpensive and yummy. And, open Xmas day. 

I had the pumpkin curry with vegetables. The coconut milk sauce tasted pretty fattening, but it sure tasted good.

Not a very big place - I think it only seats about a dozen people.
author: Philip T.

description: I've been going to this little joint for YEARS. The food is good and comes fast, which is important when you're drunk and want something greasy ASAP. Not saying that their food is super greasy, but ya, it's what the doctor ordered when you're buzzing down clement street off of a few cocktails and are in need of some thai food. Oh and they're open late night. Win!
author: Zoeboe D.

description:
The plus side to this place:

1. Quick service
2. Open late night

The down side:

1. They always seem to get my order wrong when I come to pick up.
2. A bit on the oily side
3. The food is OK. Not spectacular.
author: Tiny H.

description:
I come here often because there's not a lot of choices in late night eating and its really close to the same ol friggin bars my friends and I go to almost every week.  Straight SOS. The food here is solid except that one time I got sick along with 2 other guys after eating a hot batch of fried rice.  Thanks guys.  Actually I still come here to eat and I haven't gotten sick again so that's a good sign.

The joint isn't too big and they got that purple motif going which is interesting.  The service is like typical asian dive eateriers, not too great but adequate when you are able to flag them down.  There are only a handful of tables and everytime i go there, there's a decent crowd.  

Just order the fried chicken over fried rice and you should be good.  Don't expect great food but damn you really can't beat those prices.
author: Jason Y.

description:
We just went there today.  it's amazing small but incredible busy for being such a hole in the wall restaurant.  I prefer going to the one on sloat but if I'm shopping for groceries on clement, i don't mind coming here.  

food and service are consistent throughout this chain.

They need to open one near where I live.  

Oh yeah, noticed that they raised their prices today...but I'm still a customer.
author: Leena C.

description:
Quick, ok strike that super quick service.
I ordered a soft drink because I didn't want to drink the tap water, but apparently the ice stunk and so I was not happy.
Food is good as you eat it but once you leave you will feel greasy and will be desperately looking for a nearby water well.
That being said...I guess I would go back.  What I don't know won't hurt me until I find that hair or worm like reviewers prior to me.
I ordered a curry rice plate and was in and out within 20 minutes.  However, I didn't appreciate my waiter's thumb dip in my curry sauce.....I have seen the finger condoms and they should really consider getting some while serving anything with soup contents and that wobbles while walking.
author: Helen C.

description:
It is very important to distinguish the various Kings of Thais in San Francisco.  This location is King of Thai No. 1.  Not only is it the first King of Thai Noodle House, it's also the best.

Here's the plan: Go to 540 Club down the street and drink at least 4 pints of PBR at $2 a pint.  Glorious.  Then, check how much cash you have.  If you have $5 or less, go to Jack in the Box and brave the committee of drooling, drunk, and belligerent homeless people.  If you have $6 or more, go to the King.

Highlights: Pra Rarm (w/chicken) or the wonton soup.  I love the wonton soup here.  And, if I remember correctly, it's a giant bowl for under $6.

Important details: Great, friendly service. Hot tea.  Fast.  Fresh vegetables.  Cheap.  Delicious.  Big portions.
author: Joe R.

description:
Totally done with this freaking place!  I used to go to the one on 3rd and Clement all the time.  They are nicer and the place is big enough to sit down without ending up next to the bathroom.  When they closed it, I started ordering at the one on 8th and Clement and just getting my order to go.  I did this a few weeks ago, they said it would be "ten minutes" so I stopped off a safe 15-20 minutes later.  They still hadn't cooked my food, so I waited like five minutes and it was ready.  I was a little peeved, but no big deal.  

Today I ordered my food on the way home (STARVING!!!) and they again said "ten minutes."  By the time I found parking (this neighborhood is AWFUL for parking) it had been about 20 minutes.  I went in and they left me waiting for another five minutes before asking me what I needed.  I told them I was there for a pick up only to find that they STILL had no cooked my order!  The woman told me it would be "ten minutes" because they were busy.  I left.  

I understand that places get busy, it happens when you have pretty damned good yellow chicken curry.  But, if you aren't going to get someone's food ready in ten minutes, you should tell them that when they place their order.  Or just don't do carry out orders.  In any event, I don't care how good the food is.  If they can't actually get me the food when they say they can... it doesn't deserve any freaking stars at all!  
I only give it two stars because the one on 3rd and Clement was pretty darned good.  I wish they'd close the one on 8th and re open the one on 3rd!

If you have all day to wait or don't mind sitting next to the bathrooms while you eat... this is the place for you.  If you actually like getting the food you order... you should probably try somewhere else.  :)  

GRRRRR!!!!
author: Corey F.

description:
Whenever my boyfriend and I are too tired to cook and we don't know what we want to eat I send him off to King of Thai. It's fast, it's not all that expensive and it's all pretty tasty.

We get our usual:

Pad Thai ($6.75)
Larb Gai  ($6.75)
Nam Tok ($6.75)

All very tasty and cheap cheap cheap cheap. The three dishes with rice feeds the two of us for dinner with enough for a late night snack. Leftovers do not stand a chance in our house. It's a chain for a reason - good price for pretty good consistent food. No surprises here.
author: Wendy B.

description:
This is a bad Thai restaurant..the decor SUCKS! The food is quickly made, rushed out..no quality, no presentation.

I only been there once .I wasn't that hungry since I had a delicious roast beef sandwich from Lucca's an hour or so early, so I only ordered larb. It tasted okay. It tasted mostly of lime, fish sauce, and basil in that order. It was made with grounded beef! What is up with that? I'm used to eating larb made with juicy and tender beef cuts. Worst larb ever.

A friend got some beef over rice, he said it was alright. Two friends got pad thai which was mainly noodles with like four shrimps. Another friend got pad sa ew which was burnt, so it was sent back. He told the waitress it didn't tasting right and that it had a burnt taste. So she went back, then a waiter came with the dish and asked him what was wrong. So my friend had to repeat himself. They brought him out a new one which he said was good. So if anything, get the pad sa ew

I would not come here again.
author: Chatree T.

description:
We ordered take-out and loved it!  So yummy.  I had the veggie green curry and it was magnificent. Perfect amount of heat and tons of different vegetables.  I will probably have to get it again.  My husband had the Pad Kee Mao ( I think?) - we called it Drunken Noodles because we didn't have the menu in front of us - it was really good too.  Oh, and also Tom Yum soup - once again - very good.  I'm eating the leftovers for lunch now as I write.  Mmmm...

The interior is pretty diner-ish and they ONLY take cash.  The service was fine for take-out, they were efficient and nice.  Standing to pay was like being "in" the kitchen, two feet away they are flipping pans and plating and flipping and whew - working their a**es off.  Constantly wiping their stations down, so it seemed very clean.  We will definitely be coming back for take out!!!
author: Tracey E.

description:
Good solid food at cheap prices.  A bit divey, but who cares!

They're stir fried flat noodles (pad seeew) and basil chicken (or pork) over rice are quite tasty. When they first opened years ago, I used to sit at the counter and watch the cook prepare the dishes in the hopes that I too could cook these dishes at home. While many of their dishes are easy to prepare, I'd much rather spend a few bucks and get their take-out instead.

This was the first cheap Thai food I tried in San Francisco. Back when this place first opened, most Thai restaurants in SF were more or less sit down places with family-style menus.

Their soup noodles are also quite good.
author: J K.

description:
The FOOD IS REALLY BAD!! EXTREMELY RUDE service! DO NOT TRUST DELIVERY!

I ordered delivery: 2 dishes; Tom yum goong, spicy green beens and 2 cokes. The soup was correct but the other dish was NOT green beans, instead it was rice and vegetables which included broccoli, carrots, spinach, mushrooms, cabbage and onions (with absolutely no green beens). When I called to tell them the order was wrong they argued with me insisting  they sent me spicy green beens, I had to repeat more than 12 times that they did not send me spicy green beens. If they had sent me spicy green beens then why would I call and have them take them back? Makes no sense because I really wanted to eat spicy green beens. But they sent bland sauteed mixed vegetables. Finally they said they would send the driver back to pick it up and refund my money. It's unbelievable how EXTREMELY RUDE they were to me since they are the ones who made the mistake. Usually in business it is gracious to admit the mistake (mistakes happen) and give the customer back the money, no biggie, and be nice about it. It's called customer service, and they are in the service industry after all.

When the driver (whom I had tipped earlier) came to take the order back and refund my money, was shown that the order was not green beens - he said absolutely nothing. He just gave me back my money and I am the one that said thank you. Well guess what he said? He said, "we will never deliver to this address again."  Can you believe the level of rudeness? My mouth dropped wide open! I really could not believe he had said that. So, to sum things up: they're angry at me for their mistake - unbelievable! 

I lived in Thailand for 9 months,  I do know good Thai food and this place isn't it! The Tom yum soup was one of the worst I've ever had. The spicy green beens don't come with green beens and the cokes were warm.

*EXTREMELY RUDE service 
*They do not take pride in the food they serve 
*They mistreat their customers.

LOUSY!
author: Lydia P.

description:
the King?  doubtful,  actually...but the Pad Kee Mow totally hit the spot last night and went great with a couple eps of Parks and Recreation on netflix.

Fast service, solid work overall.  If you're into pan fried noodles (and if you're not, seriously what is your deal?) then this will do it.
author: Robert K.

description: Good, inexpensive Thai food. A small little hole in the wall, with some delicious Thai food. Everything we ordered smelled and tasted delicious. And then of course, you get the unlimited supply of tea to keep you warm on a cold San Francisco night :-)
author: Gurpreet S.

description: King of Thai noodles lives up to its name. The noodles are excellent. Not too soggy and not too chewy...they seem to have their noodles perfected. Outside of that I can't comment much. I haven't ordered anything else that's not a noodle. I haven't been back here in awhile either so I'm not too sure about the condition of the restaurant. The last I remember, it was pretty run down and dirty. Service is close to non-existent but you wouldn't expect much from a place like this anyway.
author: Eric L.

description: Yeah, I really don't get the KoT fan base.  I used to have a friend who insisted on eating here weekly (sometimes dragging me there multiple times a week) over the course of about 2 years.  I never really liked it.  The food is edible but nothing to write home about.  They're aren't many vegetarian options either, which irritates me.  But even the looks of his chicken dish just screamed mediocre to me.  Plus, one time this butch girl who works there was glaring at me through the entire meal.  I never said anything to her nor did I do anything remotely brash or offensive.  I just came in, sat down, and instantly made the top of her sh*t list.  What's yer beef, butch Thai girl??
author: Michael D.

description:
King of Thai . . . the name don't lie!

I've been ordering the same thing for about 10 years now---Thai Fried Rice with Chicken.

LOVE IT!! 

Fast, Cheap, Tasty Food! That says it all.
author: David R.

description:
THIS PLACE HAS THE MOST AMAZINGLY DELICIOUS FOOD TO OFFER.

I can't get enough of this place. I'd eat here every day if I lived in the city. Prices are ridiculously cheap (and if you can't spare 7 bucks..I'd have to call you ridiculously cheap). The service is fast, and they're open late (til 2am I believe) for your midnight cravings. Only thing is, this place is small, and not good for large groups. If you have a bigger party, go down a few blocks at the King of Thai #2. BUT, my friends and I all agree that there is a difference in the taste - and King of Thai #1 is definitely better. That wasn't meant to say the other ones are bad, they're ALL delicious.

Need a recommendation? Pad kee mao. You will not regret it.
author: Tiffany T.

description:
King of Thai Noodle House is awesome!  The best place to get Thai food on Clement Street.  I think.

Great cheap Thai food and friendly servers.  The mango sticky rice desert gets the Julie B's hands down the best ever... 

Like really ever.

Mmmmmmmm
author: julie b.

description:
Best Thai food, period. The peanut sauce is awesome. The Pad Thai is great. The curry rocks. Pad Bee Law = yum. (but you gotta add the spicy hot stuff to it.) 
The only reason they get 4 instead of 5 stars is they don't have veggie egg rolls or fried tofu.
author: Joy T.

description:
One of the things I absolutely looooove about my neighborhood is all the cheap ethnic food, many of which places are open later in the evening.

After an absolutely terrible day, what better way to cheer oneself up than to eat delicious thai food with a good friend?  Dressed in sweats and swollen eyes, I was immediately welcomed by the friendly waitress. She was attentive and kind. We ordered the Pad Kee Mow with pork and another dish with chicken, green beans, peppers in a sweet black soy sauce with steamed rice. My only complaint is that the food was very, very salty. Maybe it's because I worked in a thai restaurant for a few years where I could get my food without MSG? 

Overall, decent thai food- bang for your buck. I recommend the pad kee mow with the soft thick noodles! Delicous!
author: Laura D.

description: This is not the place to go if you're trying to impress someone with ambiance and beautifully plated food, but if you're looking for great Thai with lots of options and on the fly, the King of Thai is your calling. I have been going here for years and for years they've been filling my hankerings Thai. If you like wonton soup and love some great flavor in the broth, for their #10. I order it without the vegetables and add in some vermicelli noodles. Also a good pick is their pad thai or the pad kee mao. This place is a great go to for when you just want some good, cheap, delicious Thai food. And they're open really late. But don't forget it's cash only, but there's a BofA atm right across the street..
author: Rebecca D.

description:
If you love noodles in beef broth and you find yourself in san Francisco, you have to try the beef noodles in king of thai.

Every time I travel to the bay area, this is the first stop when I get off the plane.  If I had to pick one casual dining choice in all of north America, this is the place, and the beef noodle is the dish.

The interior decor and exterior facade say bargain basement, but the food is what makes this place unique.

Though I've tried other dishes here, it's the noodles that brings me back.

Think of Pho, with all the sliced beef, now add morning glory and other exotic herbs, make the broth 10 times stronger with condiments and spices so addictive that they should be illegal, and you will know what I'm talking about.

Yes.  Add the pickled habanero, this noodle broth will make your taste buds sing.

The thai milk tea complements the dish well, but it's pretty average as a drink, it just goes well with the noodles.

Over time, I've tried other locations of king of thai, sometimes with disappointing results.  This location is pretty consistent, even if it looks grungy, I still go back.
author: Patrick T.

description: Aren't Thai restaurants in SF a dime a dozen? King of Thai is good if it's really late and you don't have much money and you don't really care about taste quality. I mean, you do get what you pay for. Cheap food usually isn't always good. Maybe I've been ordering the wrong things but the last couple of times I've been here it has been less than stellar. I'm thinking I should just stick with pad thai. Hard to mess that up.
author: David C.

description: This place has saved me many times from getting food at jack in the box and 711.  The food is made fresh and you can watch it being made.   It is fairly fast and open late.  If you call it in and head over there most likely it is ready and waiting.  The only down side is that you need to pay cash, no credit card.  Luckily the atm is a block away.  Good service and if you plan to dine in it is a nice setting, fairly small but it feels homey.  There is a restroom, but I think its for customers, so go buy yourself some fried rice go to the bathroom and get you food.
author: Kendal T.

description:
Great Thai...Loving Clement street more and more...Truly the KING of Thai

Tom Yum soup is really fantastic, IMHO...I give it the edge over Osha (And I'm an Osha devotee)...Nice hint of coriander comes out too...But also like Osha, they seem to go very skimpy on the tomatoes.

Curry dishes are terrific too although a little watery compared to others I've had.

Food was prepared fresh and quickly...Great experience.

My only con would be that I think the tables are a bit narrow for the plates/bowls they bring out to you...We barely had a molecule of space to maneuver on the table between that and drinks.

Would say you can't get any party bigger than 4 in there either.

DEFINTELY going to go back. my favorite place for Thai in the city...Yummm
author: Barca F.

description:
I'm impressed with this place because of 2 things... the prices are cheap and the food is actually pretty good for being cheap.

If you haven't been here... I will order this if I were you:

Pad Thai
Pad See Ew
Tom Yum Kai 
Som Tom (Papaya Salad, medium spiciness)
Thai Egg Rolls
Yellow Curry
And any other thing you can pronounce.

Hope it helps... enjoy biatches!
author: Miguel B.

description:
I only come here for their Thai noodle soups.  Affordable food.  Its a small place but I don't care because its one of those places for a quick eat meal.

I noticed recently that the portion are smaller than before.
author: A P.

description:
We went here yesterday after 3 hours of badminton. I am impressed. The place is not pretentious, the food is outstanding and very close to authentic Thai food you would get in Thailand. The only boo-boo is the chicken. I want it deep fried. But it wasn't and the chicken is sour. Too bad I can't remember all the foods we ordered. Must be the muscle aches and exhaustion. LOL!

Other than that, I like the place. Would go there again. For the price, taste and service, I give it a 4-star.
author: ASIANDIVAH A.

description:
Took my parents here a few months ago for some "good" Thai and it was embarrassing. The food was SO oily! I kept wiping my mouth with each bite and my parents couldn't even finish their noodles. 

Quite surprising since the first time I ate at King of Thai, the food was decent. Either the chef had an off-day or I was lucky the first time around. There are better Thai places out there, even if it's the other King of Thai down the street.
author: Jane K.

description: Why isn't a minus 10 available, yelp??! Because I so would give this place a negative 10. I lived in the Inner Richmond for nearly three years but moved away last year, so I haven't been back to this place in about a year. And I guess in the interim the only 3 nasty bitchy Thai people in the world got hired to work here. Because I have found that Thai people are always much much nicer than people of other nationalities. I came here with my family for dinner, and apparently the three waitresses working are the witches in Macbeth or from some Edgar Allan Poe story. It was quite bizarre because, again, I have never encountered nasty bitchy Thai people. But, guess what, bitches? We got to try Sakesan across the street and spent our money there instead, and the wait staff were all efficient, friendly, helpful, and spoke and understood English even over the booming music and karaoke. So, I don't know what the fuck was up your asses but we are taking our money to Sakesan because we will be throwing fundraisers and parties there and the food was rocking delicious. I feel bad for the owners of King of Thai - your waitresses are making your restaurant and country look bad. Sakesan also has a much much nicer ambiance. After ordering an appetizer at King of Thai, I tried to order main dishes, and I don't know what the fuck was wrong with these Weird Sisters, but they apparently really wanted to insult a customer. So, I told them we would only pay for the appetizer and that we were leaving because of their fucking attitude. I don't even know how some people like such Weird Witches can have a job when there are good people who would be happy to have a job and be nice to paying customers. If you're still reading, go to Sakesan! Or Trader Joe's. This place sucks. Unless they fire the Weird Bitches.
author: Frank S.

description:
I wasn't sure what to expect when I was told by one friend that it was good and by another that it was not but decided to come here for myself to decide.

It's a hole in the wall but the food is definitely authentic and delicious. I ordered the green papaya salad and the red curry with duck, my usual at any Thai restaurant. Both dishes were very flavorful. Also, their prices are very reasonable but I wouldn't suggest coming here with a large party because it's kind of small.
author: Jin I.

description: Open late and I always get a seat! I think my favorite has switched from Duck Fried Rice to the Pork Blood Soup! OOOOH, so good. Seriously I'd never have Pork Blood ever.. not even in my congee, but it tastes like prime rib in this soup. doitdoitdoit
author: Eda L.

description:
this is more like solid 3.5 stars.

+1 star - open late
+1 star - super cheap!
+1 star - wait staff very friendly
+1 star - portions are huge!
+1 star - food my friends got was really good (pad woon sen and green curry something...)
-1 star - do not accept credit cards
-0.5 star - my No. 16 was too salty for my taste and had a ton of imitation crab meat and fishcakes (fake stuff is a no-no in my eating book) 

Will most likely go back next time i'm having drinks in the neighborhood...
author: Suzanna G.

description: I like this place because 1. I'm a fan of places that stay open late, 2. Thai food is always great 3. My order (pad thai noodles) was satisfying... Enough said!
author: kathy h.

description:
Quick and friendly service. Parking could be a hassle on weekends.

I had the red beef curry. It definitely hit the spot considering just coming back to real food after a draining camping trip. But I would have to say I have had better curry dishes. It was a bit bland compared to a curry dish I would consider great. Good but not the best. 

My friend's had Pad Thai and Pad See Ew both dishes were massive in portion and looked very tasty. Will try one of those dishes on a future visit.

The portions were perfect, maybe even a lot to some.

Would come back.
author: Drew T.

description: Ok, I just came back to this place for the second time after the New Years fireworks. They have alot of variety of noodle soups and specials. This is one of the places where you cant get tired of eating.
author: Ramon S.

description:
good portion size and the food hit the spot.  service was attentive as my tea and water never went below the 1/2 mark.

had spicy eggplant, pad see ew, green curry... and i liked them in that order.

the only thing that kind of bugged was where we were seated.. huge draft everyt ime anyone came into and out of the restaurant.
author: Elaine G.

description: Good food. Otherwise quite average and satisfactory. But again, it's a restaurant, food is the important part. I will go again and again for the good food.
author: Lance C.

description: Very tasty, surprisingly cheap and fresh.  Reminds me more of Chinese food than Thai.  Really fast service for takeout.  I would much rather stop by here and get something fresh for a few more dollars than go to one of the many to-go places surrounding the area.  The cool part is also basically half the restaurant is the open kitchen, so if you can watch the cooks make your food as you are waiting.  Fun touch.
author: M R.

description:
I feel like I cant really go wrong at this place... I mean like really wrong where you get that feeling "LIKE OMG WHAT IN THE HECK DID I ORDER?"
Its tasty thai food for a good price, and its fast too... thats ALWAYS GREAT!!!
author: Shadae H.

description:
The food was excellent, had the flat noodle basil beef. Didn't really like the sun roof blinding me from above however, so if you go in the daytime - wear your sunglasses.

The duck fried rice sounds amazing, i will go back for this!
author: wayne s.

description:
KING OF THAI!

Probably just a step up from Tu Lan (my favorite place ever.)  Only achievable by the fact it lacks the smell of used malt liquor and other things I dare not mention here.  Read that review if you really must know...

King of Thai is a taste of San Francisco.  Each delectable bite or slurp is perfect.  Simple but wonderful nonetheless.

You can wake up around noonish, walk down the street in your PJs and enjoy something cheap and wonderful.

But don't be fooled, it can also be a great place for a date or even meeting a few friends from work.

It's great!

Their Duck Noodle soup is just so good it's burned permanently into my conscious.  Plus they can make almost anything vegetarian.  Finally, I think this is where I got hooked on Hale's Blue Boy syrup they run out on occasion but if you want to try something like heroin, but legal, give it a try.

This is the reason to live near Clement.
author: Francisco G.

description: I was next door at the dim sum restaurant, and while walking out, I had a strange craving for some pad thai. So I ended up at this restaurant. I definitely enjoyed their pad thai here -- it was really delicious! The portion was huge, seemed impossible for one person to finish the plate alone. Their tom yum soup was also really tasty! It had the perfect blend of spices and flavor. Oh and on top of their food being yummy, it comes out extremely fast! I swear within 2 minutes of ordering, the waiter came out with the soup, then another minute, the pad thai arrived. I love not having to wait forever for my food! Great place for some thai food! I will definitely come back to try their other items the next time im in town.
author: Cathy N.

description:
king of THIGH, as i like to call you...




i love you. i love you for your good food. i love you for being open late. i love you for your ever so lavender walls that are like music for my eyes when i see you after a long night of alcohol. i just love you.
author: Justine K.

description:
Hands down, this is the best Thai place for the price!!

I used drive from Daly City to here, which is about 20 minutes, a couple times a week to eat here. Now that they opened one on Sloat, that one is a lot closer for me.

I've tried many items on the menu, and I love all of them! Everything is so delicious! And the pricing is very good! This restaurant has large portions. I can never finish one whole plate on my own. However, the restaurant on Sloat has a bit smaller portions.

Anyways, if you're looking for a delicious Thai place that's good for the money, this is definitely the place to be.

PLUS, it's a really good late night dinner because they close late!
author: Alice L.

description: Great for a quick cheap bite. Everything I've had there has been pretty good. Good simple Thai dishes, this is not a fancy Thai restaurant but a good little noodle joint to grab a dish. I'm a fan of their Pad Kee Mao with chicken and also think their yellow curry has nice flavoring as well. You really can't go to wrong with most items and the prices are right.
author: Chris N.

description: You go to this place for one REASON and one reason only... Late Night after drinkie and you order DUCK FRIED RICE.  This magic dish will take all the horrible things away and create a land of utopia and justice.
author: Joseph P.

description: The best thai boat noodle place in the US. This is the first place I have to go to when I touch down in SF. Everything else is great too but something about this broth just keeps me going back. The fried chicken over fried rice is really good here too.
author: Boon K.

description: I ordered food at lunch for take-out and didn't realize that they gave me the wrong change until I got to my destination.  I called to let them know that they shorted me $10 on my change.  They said they would check and call back.  When they did call back of course they didn't see any overage in their accounting.  Very dishonest!  It is unfortunate that I will never go back to this place again!!
author: Rebekah D.

description:
I'll be the first to admit that this is probably not the highest quality Thai food in San Francisco. Yet, for the price, and the speed at which the food is prepared, you can't complain. Any time I have a craving for Thai food, this is where I go. While others may branch out to the other King of Thais, I stick with the original; because I'm a food snob like that.

The staff is always friendly, eager to help, and if they ever do miss something, they're more than willing to correct themselves. I especially love the fact that within a few minutes after ordering (I can't imagine it's ever been more than 10) my food arrives hot and ready to be enjoyed.

Clearly, this isn't an upscale place to write home and brag to relatives about. But it's a damn good neighborhood spot that is consistent in its tastiness. Also, you usually get quite a bit of food for the price. I make it a point to try the Pad See Ew at every Thai place I ever go to, and so far this is the best one I've tried. Only downside is if you don't have cash on hand, you better be prepared to run to an ATM. So, If you like Thai food (especially the curries and noodles) give this place a shot.
author: Mitchell L.

description:
We were on our way to Burma Star, but somehow missed our turn when they called us to be seated.  Rather than wait another 10-15 minutes we decided to head over to King of Thai NH up the street.

The menu looked good and who can go wrong with a place that has been rated "Best Noodles" by Asia Weekly Mag ;)  It's also interesting to note that their Health Inspection Bill is posted out front with a 91 rating (my guess is that this is REALLY good).  And while I don't mind hitting up hole in the walls for tasty bites, I love it when it's clean too.

We walked in to a very clean, cafeteria style looking environment.  Definitely don't go for the ambiance (i/e/ not a date place), but it is very clean.

We ordered 3 dishes: 1. Tom Kha Gai (Coconut soup w chicken), 2. Chicken Gang Panang (red curry), and 3. Guay Tiew Lord (flat rice noodles with shrimp, ground chicken, tofu, egg and mushrooms in sweet black soy) which was served with rice.

The Tom Kha Gai was one of the best I've had in the city.  Not only were the spices perfect, but the chicken was lean and clean.  If there's one this I can't stand it's tough meat or fatty meat.  (OSHA THAI: PAY ATTENTION).

All were scrumptios and the bill came to $22.50.  We both left stuffed with enough left overs for another meal plus.  Now, that's what I  call good eats....!

The service was OK, not great, but not too bad either.

I can't wait to eat my leftovers for lunch tomorrow.
I am definitely coming back here.
author: DJ N.

description: Usually I go to other King of Thai locations out of convenience (especially the one on Sloat at Lakeshore Plaza) and because I don't hang out at that part of Clement St as much these days.  Still I have to give a positive rating to this location because it's the original one and it's the place that gave me my initial exposure to Thai noodle.  Back then the experience was excellent.  It's not surprising they succeeded in making this a mini-franchise in SF.
author: H K.

description:
cheap, fast, and open late (2:30!) this is not by any means elegant dining, it's the 'wow, i'm drunk and hungry, what will hit the spot?' DEFINITELY king of thai. the menu is large (you've got ~5 pages of options) and the food is pretty tastey. 

ranges from $5-$10 for most dishes - avg. being $7.95.
author: linda t.

description: Horrible Horrible!!! went there last Saturday night and found a fried fly in my noodles!!!!! Never going back there again. It was my first and last time.
author: Claudia F.

description:
A small hole in the wall feeling to this restaurant. One small TV, but changing the channel to a sports program or MTV is super easy with the remote right next to it (Easy enough!). 

- Thai Iced Tea: Super sweet and strong. I literally diluted it about 4 times throughout my meal with a little water added every time I took a sip, but really refreshing (especially with all the spices). I probably could have made two drinks from my 1 cup. 
- Pad Thai (chicken): No lemon wedge for you to squeeze, but it already had the citrusy taste to it. Our chicken pad thai came with nicely flavored noodles, chicken, tofu, bean sprouts, green onion, peanuts. 
- Yellow curry (chicken): I'm sad that they did not add a variety of vegetables similar to other Thai restaurants that I've been to. This dish consisted of yellow onions, chicken, and potatoes. There was a little kick of spiciness to it (not too much), but it was delicious and perfect. Not too sweet, not too salty, great with the side of white rice and it even tasted good drenched on top of the pad thai (After one taste of this curry, the pad thai became bland, so eat your noodles first!). This came with a side of pickled cucumber and purple onions too (just a hint of vinegar taste to it). 

Service was quick and efficient. Sitting inside the restaurant gives you an aroma of spices that will literally tickle your nose. It's small, but we were immediately seated on a Monday night here. Although, I observed many to-go orders that were placed throughout my meal here (not a bad idea if this place gets really busy). 

P.S. There is also a King of Thai #2 down the busier side of Clement St. near all the shops that are opened late versus this one that has shops that are closed all around it (Easier to find parking though).
author: Tracy T.

description: Since I lived in Thailand for a period of time, I just can't give them the five stars, although I would like too just for the woks they use...  This place really does rock for a local thai noodle shop.  The duck curry is great, but I wish they would get rid of the cherry tomatoes.  The pad thai is exactly what you would expect, the tom yum is decent and the noodle dish with the eggplant, which I can't remember it's name is also kickin GOOD!
author: lane k.

description: I was expecting a lot out of this place, since all the people I know that has eaten here give it rave reviews. I ordered the chicken with squash curry and rice, and the tom yum soup with shrimp. I thought the food was decent for fast thai food but nothing that really struck me as awesome. Maybe I had too high expectations. Overall experience was ok, fast service and pretty nice people. The portion size was good for price.
author: Tiffany L.

description: I've been to about 4 other KoT's in the city (Haight, Downtown, Sloat, and Taraval) and this by far the best. It's the cleanest, the tastiest, and has impeccable service. I always come hungry and always leave completely satisfied. The waiters are very attentive and refill waters often and the food is comparatively tastier than the other 4. I personally order the fried rice with pork and chinese sausage (SO GOOD!) and the tomato they have on the side hasn't been sour.
author: Anita W.

description: there are so many king of thai! but my boyfriend especially love this one! we came here a few times already! although this place is small and its cash only, the service here is great! and the food here is delicious. but please note that this place dont have any high chairs or booster is you're thinking about coming here with a kid or baby.
author: Winnie C.

description: Came here on a monday because all my other favorite thai places were closed (what's up with that by the way)?   It was more pricey than I was accustomed to and there were no combinations or lunch specials... I ordered the pineapple fried rice, which was a "chef's Special."  It was fairly bland and the only real flavor was the canned pineapple.  I won't be back
author: Sage S.

description: Thai is absolutely my favorite food.  This place on Clement is the BEST for green curry.  Hands down.  I am a green curry fanatic and these guys make it right.  It is the perfect hotness, pretty dang hot.  The other food we order is always delicious too and my family loves it.  They are always nice to us there and always bring water for my 4 year-old in a plastic cup with a lid.  Smart.  It's cash only, a bummer for me, but totally worth it.  I live in Oakland now, I have yet to try the King of Thai in the Alameda.  I hope it's as good!
author: Stasia T.

description: Strangely bland Thai food. I have no real complaints except the meat in the thai beef salad seemed to be boiled. Also had a ground porky chickeny deep fried with sweet sauce thing. Wasn't bad, just unremarkable. Food was inexpensive if you order just one thing. Service was excellent but not friendly. Cash Only.
author: Mark B.

description:
When life is taking a proverbial piss on me, I let it roll off me, take a hot shower, throw on some sweats, and stroll on down to King of Thai Noodle House #1. This is my comfort food, my favorite go-to restaurant in the City.

It's a hole in the wall that seats maybe two dozen, but there's always room for me, and almost never a line. The service is kind, and the food warms the soul -- it's authentic, unpretentious, and simple. This place isn't about atmosphere or trendiness. It's not there to be the fanciest, best Thai food in the city. It's about feeding you good food when you need it most, day or night. I can't say the same for the dozen other KoT locations citywide -- even though they share the same menu, the service is what sets #1 apart from the rest.

My comfort food recommendations:
5. Guay Tiew Moo Look Chin Pla -- noodles with sliced pork, ground pork, sliced fish cakes, fish balls and bean sprouts in clear chicken soup (you have a choice of noodles -- I suggest egg noodles with this). Light and easy, not too salty.
16. Guay Thew Lord -- sauteed shrimps ground chicken calamari tofu dried shrimps with white onion, been sprouts black mushroom in sweet black soy sauce and served over steamed dal rice noodles. The sweet soy sauce sets this dish apart from the rest, and is very filling for the days when you're absolutely starving.
31. Kao Pad Gai Tod deep fried boneless chicken breast over fried rice with egg , white onion, tomatoes, topped with cilantro and cucumber, and served with sweat and sour sauce. Nothing says comfort food like fried rice.
43. Tom Kha Gai -- Thai style chicken soup with coconut milk, mushroom, galangal, and lemongrass. If you're craving soup, this will give you a spicy kick without the strong acidity of most Thai soups.

After twelve years of living off of Clement, I've probably eaten here a hundred times, half of them after midnight. I know there will always be a pot of hot tea waiting for me.
author: Perci N.

description: The food is great!  The staff is friendly and its open late!  What more do you need?
author: Thomas A.

description: Let me preface with I know nothing about Thai food, that being said I enjoy this place, it's fast and a decent price and imfind the food delicious.
author: M. R. C.

description: Walking in the smells emanating from this place are fantastic, full, and rich.  Try to keep from drooling.  I ordered what is essentially a sweet and sour shrimp.  It was okay.  I sampled my friend's spicy chicken and cashews with rice, and that was GREAT!  Next time, I'm having what the server recommends.  No credit cards accepted so bring cash.
author: Richard R.

description: great thai food, went for the first time had tom ka, pad thai, and green curry all great :) lots of flavor. will absolutely go back again.
author: michael d.

description: I've never been to a restaurant as many times as I've been to King of Thai.  I usually get take out from here once or twice a week.  I can't say much about ambiance of the place although I really enjoy watching the skilled chefs cook and make my food while waiting.  They seem very experienced and make a great Pad Thai, Pineapple Fried Rice, and Chicken Satay.
author: Stephen G.

description:
there's like a dozen king of thai on clement street. ;)

the food is pretty good. pretty typical thai food. the best is the pad khee mao (sp?) it's a real fresh flavor and doesn't sit too heavily in the stomach. plus, the prices are real decent. i think about $8 on average?
author: Turtle W.

description: Number 30 is what I always get. And apparently every other Yelper does too! Humongous portions that put me into a food coma even if I didn't even finish a quarter of it.
author: Pearl R.

description: I love the green papaya salad here.  It is made just as spicy as in Thailand, and so fresh.  I come here just for this!
author: Emily D.

description:
I tried the duck noodle soup with chinese herb duck broth (wide flat thin noodle) during my first visit here. However, I found that the noodles are kind of hard to get hold of (I need to try the other noodle), but this has nothing to do with the taste or quality of the food.

The broth was really delicious as it contains those chinese herbs which you could find in bah kut teh, i believe. The duck meat is well marinated too. Love it.

I am not sure about other king of thai, but this is a good one.
author: Finu L.

description:
Thai food has always been so dear to my heart. On a foggy day in San Francisco, yellow curry with potatoes is a great comfort food dish that warms the heart. Many Thai dishes are light in taste but infused with many flavors. After interviewing the King of Thai chef, I learned that different sauces blend well with different dishes. The papaya salad is a great example of a great spring starter. Thinly slice papaya sliced and mixed with a tart dressing. Below is a review I wrote for the local newspaper I work for. At the end of this blog, I will address more about how restaurateurs approach financing.

In a city peppered with Thai restaurants, picking one for dinner can be as daunting as making your own pad thai blindfolded. But fear not, just make a beeline to King of Thai on Clement Street. It's a fast casual dining restaurant reflecting chef- owner Anthony Chaichana original intentions of serving affordable Thai cuisine.

Decorated lavender walls, it's hard to miss despite being on eatery row on Clement. As a tribute to the King and Queen of Thailand, gold framed portraits dress the barren back wall. Dressed in purple shirts and expressing an anxious smile, servers scurry around the sixty seat restaurant. Trying not to be overwhelmed by extensive menu and hard to pronounce dishes, focus on choosing key ingredients and the method of cooking from boiling to stir fry

For starters, the fresh duck salad special ($6.75) stimulates the appetite. Savory duck meat and fat from the skin, the dish is complimented by sprinkles of chopped mints. Raw cabbage, red and green onions provide crunch while the chili- lime dressing adds a tangy flavor. In gang graree ($6.75), sweet chopped onions lay alongside soft buttery potatoes all bathe in a smooth milky yellow curry sauce. A few spoonfuls of curry over the mound of fluffy white rice result in comfort food paradise. Refreshing the plate, a small serving of cucumber salad add crunch and tangy flavor. For flavor thrill seekers, two spoonfuls of vinegar jalepeno from the spice rack will enhance the ride. As their name suggest, the restaurant is famous for their noodles. Beef lovers should try the beef stew noodle-$5.75. Acting as the core of the dish, the sweet flavored soup is extracted from hours of brewing beef meat and bones but more distinctly, the overuse of rock sugar. Taking a bird's eye view of the dish, it looks likes a collection of beef offerings. The beef balls lack flavor, only providing a bouncy texture but the thin slices of beef were flavorful. The best meat ingredient, beef stew pieces feature a coat of gelatinous tendon with a brisket under layer. Soften by the minute, the noodles were nothing spectacular. Bean sprouts provide crunch and wilted spinach add an earthy taste to the otherwise heavy noodle soup.
