Skip the pork noodle soup -$5.75 (soup simmered with ground and slice pork along with fish cake and balls) which lacks flavor in soup and ingredients.

Crowned the best dish of the night, the koa pad gai tod ($7.25) is all about crunch. Boneless chicken breast coated with a thin batter is fried till gold brown served over a mound of fried rice. Made pungent from eggs, pillow white rice compliments the sweet onions and tomatoes. Dunk the chicken into the sweet and sour sauce as a flavor enhancer. Having dined at other sister locations, I would suggest their pad thai-$6.75. Cooked al dente, the noodles are chewy and seep into their acetous sauce. With a refreshing spicy lime dressing, the papaya salad flavored with dry shrimps and peanuts is a great choice for cooling appetizer-$6.45. With a taffy like texture, the sticky rice and mango dessert end a good meal. For a party of four, the total came out to $11 per person.

As a new immigrant to the United States in 1994, Chaichana started his first location with loans from friends and maxing out the limit on his credit cards. Despite working long hours, he stay focused with his goal of bringing wok style street food to San Franciscans. His early customers included foreign Thai students and community. By word of mouth, the business became thriving. Also crediting his great people skills, Chaichana said, "I like to spoil my customers. I give discounts and free desserts to my customers." Fourteen years later and six restaurants in his reins, he has continued to serve flavorful dishes while keeping core culinary root taught by his mother.

King of Thai Noodle is a good value eatery that targets stir fried dishes and rice plates. With quick food preparation, moderate prices, and decent quality, King of Thai noodle is a good neighborhood choice for Thai food.
author: Rayfil W.

description:
I love this place as well *yes, all of them* they are the closest thing I've had to the cart food just outside of BKK.

The duck there is awesome, and their soups rock.

Definitely a decent "home style" thai place.
author: Mark C.

description: pumpkin curry and #5 noodle soup. both very good would get again next time! real small place. only about 5 tables available. I would probably go to a bigger king of thai location instead.
author: Helen L.

description: This is Thai Fast Food.  This King of Thai is the best one in the city all others  have major flaws like bad service or skimpy portions.  This place is pretty good for late night hungry man quests.
author: erik e.

description: Enjoyed the most amazing pumpkin curry,  rich flavor, soft combination of creamy milk sauces and tasty pumpkin.  A must when in SF.
author: Raphael T.

description: I really like this spot. I tried all the Thai places in the immediate area and this place is the best for 'street style' thai. I take lots of friends here and like to drop by after the shit show is over at the local bar. Having sampled several things on the menu, I've landed on ordering the Gang Panang frequently. I would also recommend the yellow curry, green curry, nam tok, pad prik king and pra ram here. Pad thai is solid. I can spout off about a lot of dishes, you just have to find what you like. This is a Richmond landmark with badass hours + helpful staff, they get a 5er.
author: Sven S.

description: The noodles are pretty decent tasting and the dessert is the best.  If your searching for a light and inexpensive Thai cuisine this is a great choice.  Most Thai restaurants are over priced and serve small portions.  Pretty much you get what you pay for in this restaurant.  King of Thai Noodles is splat right in the middle of Sf Downtown so beware, you just might pass right by it.
author: Tiffany D.

description: Five star hole in the wall Thai restaurant specializing in noodles and curry.  Have the pad thai if you want but their noodles and curry will blow you away.  Fast, cheap, delicious - if I'm ever in the area, regardless if I'm hungry or not, I make a stop.  Remember, #5 w/ small rice noodles = )
author: Grover G.

description: Best place for authentic (cheap) thai food. This is a restaurant that serves as one of our core restaurant (one of our "comfort" food places). We always enjoy the pad-see-eew (fat noodles pan fried), larb (pork salad) and red curry (with duck). Cash only, make sure you have enough! There can be a wait if you arrive at peak hours. Parking is tough in this neighborhood, will likely have to circle around (take any space you find).
author: Jesse W.

description: I miss you, King of Thai!  I miss your duck noodle soup (with flat noodles) and your fried rice with the chinese sausage.  I miss you, oh so much!  *sob*
author: Suz K.

description: The noodle soup is miss or hit . I went there a few time 2 of 4 time was just okay the beef was just wasn't so good hard like wood but smiling staff  that sell I think
author: jose m.

description: maybe we ordered the wrong dishes, but the pad thai, chicken vermicelli soup, and beef salad, and we didn't like any of them. i think it's hard to find a good, fresh, nongreasy pad thai, since it's the equivalent of fried rice. true to form, this pad thai tasted not fresh. the chicken in the soup was dry, though my partner liked the sweet-ish broth. will not come back.
author: Zoe L.

description: Good food, reasonable price, stays open late = great night snack! You can definitely count on some pretty quick service here. The noodle soups and the fried thin rice noodles are both tasty! However, you usually end up smelling like your food when you leave the place.
author: Topazskye L.

description:
Wow, this place has been here since I was a young child. I used to come here all the time during my high school years for lunch or dinner. Still one of my favorite places to dine at with my friends. Two of my most favorite dishes I order from King of Thai are: Thai Fried Rice with fried chicken and Pad Thai. This location is quite small compared to the other close-by King of Thai Noodle House 2. So if you're planning to dine in with some friends, take them to the 2nd location near by.

Overall, they've got good food and good customer service. A definite place to drop by if you haven't already.
author: A R.

description: Today was my third visit in the last two months. Nothing disappointed me. The food and service are always outstanding. I love item # 38 - Yellow curry With Chicken, Rice and veggies - Wow is great stuff!
author: S K.

description: Not good, went there at 7:20 on a Sunday night and the place was jammed. I  stood in line and ordered Chicken satay, Shrimp Pad Thai, and Beef Pad See Lew as takeout. Finally standing around 23 minutes after ordering, I got my food. Chicken was paper like thinly sliced and had a strange taste unless dipped in peanut sauce to mask the charred fried flavor. Only got 5 very small shrimp in the pad Thai, made with very small noodles and found shrimp shells mixed in with the noodles. Not what I'm usually familiar with. The Pad See Lew was overly greasy but tasted etter than the rest. Fore being soo busy I have no idea why people go there or maybe I just ordered the wrong items. However I definitely wont be back and am going to try the place around the corner.
author: Trev D.

description: This place is literally transported from Pratet Thai (Thailand) itself.  Extremely authentic offerings, with menu items in Thai and English.  Will make anything spicy (Thai-spicy, not wimpy-I-like Pace-Picante-sauce-"spicy").  Papaya Salad (Som Tum) and Chicken Salad (Laab Gai -- it is not a mayonnaise vehicle like it sounds) are among the best I've had stateside.  Also try the chili-basil noodles with shrimp or chicken.  The duck over rice is also excellent.  Open til 1AM when last I checked so not a bad option for after a late movie etc.  If you like sickenly-sweet and tomatoey pad thai from the Cheesecake Factory -- and think that offering is tasty and authentic, then try King of Thai Noodle House to see what the real deal is all about, 'cause what you've had to date is like believing an Old El Paso crunchy taco is a real taco!
author: Xander S.

description: I had the deep fried chicken breast over fried rice.  Pretty tasty.  But the real allure are the friendly family-run owners/workers.  Nice peeps to learn or practice your thai on...
author: Vinh N.

description: I tend to frequent this location of King of Thai after a few drinks at the local watering hole.  My standbys are yellow curry with chicken or the #17 with chicken.  I don't bother trying to remember the name of the dish.  When I'm sick, the soups are great.  Cheap, decent food that open is late!
author: Dominique K.

description:
great place esp. for late night dinners
this one is also the best king of thai in the city. 
food comes quick.
dont come here much anymore because id go here plenty of times when i was in college at usf. but its really good and cheap.
try #31, #17 and the pad thai. 
CASH ONLY (the only inconvenience, but theres wamu across the st)
author: emily p.

description:
My wife liked the Pad Thai well enough, but the chicken in my red pumpkin curry is as tough as leather.  And the curry consists mostly of filler (i.e., onions and peppers) rather than actual food like chicken or veggies.  At least it didn't cost that much.

But there are way too many better options on Clement for me to consider going back to this place.
author: Patrick S.

description: My bf and I are regulars at this lil restaurant. It's open late, prices are reasonable, service is fast and the food is great. i think they have like 20 other restaurants scattered somewhere around the city too.
author: Monica D.

description: I'm always on a mission to find the best thai ice tea in town and I always find myself double parked in front of this restaurant for a small $2.50 Thai Ice Tea. Every sip hits the spot. Also, their food is tasty, my personal favs: Duck Fried Rice and Yellow Curry chicken. I'm hungry just thinking about these dishes. Only downside of this restaurant is the space, it's pretty cramped, but whatever, good food nonetheless!
author: Ruth R.

description:
don't you just love hole in the walls with good fast service, that matches the food.   First your greeted with the "yelp" sticker on the door and once you enter you're in the kitchen watching/smelling/salivating over the food preperation.  

in the mood for thai food, not noodles,we  tried the pad thai(excellent) and  Pumpkin Curry. the pumpkin meal was ok, nothing special, certainly not bad.  Not sure if I had crazy hunger but had to order a third entree to satisfy two of us.  

being halloween evening they were participating in the neighborhood as children came in dressed up for candy, that was perhaps the best part!
author: James H.

description: Their soups are great and they have so many to choose from. It's a hole in the wall, but what do you expect?
author: Devon M.

description: Love the coconut soup. Cheap, hot and fast.
author: Sherie R.

description: Our place for Thai food.  Creature of habit again.  Papaya salad, fried rice with duck, and the flat noodles with chinese broccoli and beef.  It's too long between trips now that I don't make it into the city that often.  Had the papaya salad extra spicy once.  For some reason I didn't really notice the effects until about halfway through.  You get to a point when more spicy doesn't even matter.  It's the only time when I really couldn't taste my food anymore and the inside of my mouth felt like I just had filling put in (novocaine numbness).  I know my limits now.  Great place.
author: Brad K.

description: This place is a great hole in the wall when you are in the mood for a good hearty thai meal.  The noodle bowls which they are famous for are definitely wonderful. The curry is amazing no matter which type you get, and the other chef's specials are also very satisfying.  Try the appetizers or just  go right into the meals.  Either way you will leave this place happy, full, and your pockets will be thanking you for the wise choice in cheap eats.
author: Maria B.

description: I go to King of Thais so often that I'm getting a little sick of it, but I do like them. Everything I've ordered on the menu seems to be good, maybe not special, but very tasty and filling in the end. It's clean, really cheap, and this one opens til 2:30 in the morning for us insomniacs, so I've got to give it my stamp of approval.
author: Bill K.

description: I had the duck rice plate and it was absolutely delicious!  I love the way they debone the duck for you and when you add in the spinach and sauce they put on the rice, you definitely have a winner!  My wife had the pad thai noodles and she enjoyed it, although the bean sprouts and veggies to noodles ratio was a bit lopsided, favoring the veggies.  We also had an appetizer of shrimp and stuff with a tofu skin wrapping that also was quite delicious.  We will definitely be coming back again, soon!
author: W J.

description: Roast duck noodle soup is piping hot, and infused with flavors.  I love how you can pick different types of noodles.  The rice dishes are pretty good especially you can add a fried egg on top.  It's a hole-in-the wall with tasty quick bites.
author: MooMoo L.

description: GOD I love this place. The portions are fantastic, particularly if you are selfish like me and don't like to do the whole family style thing. I want to go in, order what I want, and eat it like an rabid dog. I used to live right around the corner from this place. I highly recommend..I think it's the #16..wide noodles with a soy based sauce. It comes with shrimp, ground chicken, calamari, etc. It's sooooo good! The staff is also always friendly and helpful as well.
author: kristen v.

description: Went here with 2 of my bud's on a saturday night and we got sat down right away. just an fyi that i hadnt eaten all day which leads to a heightend dining experience.  I ordered the green curry which had the right spice and overall tasted good. service was good from what i can remeber and the only real complaint is that the place was cash only . would def go back if in the neighborhood agaian with the munchies
author: d l.

description: Thai food you want?  I'd come here.  Food is good and prices are more than fair.  That should be enough reason.
author: Louie N.

description: Open until 1 am - super fast and good food. Cash only though so be warned.  Located next to local cool bars it hits the spot for a nice quick dinner or a late night fix!
author: J S.

description:
A great place to stop by for a quick bite.  My favorite has always been "33. Kao Pad Moo Dang Goon Chiang fried rice with roasted pork and chinese sausage,egg, white onion, tomatoes, and topped with cilantro and cucumber".

It always hits the spot! The price is right, the place is fairly clean, and the quality is consistent every time.
author: Antonio E.

description: This is my favorite noodle place in San Francisco and maybe even the world outside of Thailand. It is the home of my favorite meal in San Francisco, which is #17 - Pad Kee Mao (with chicken). Folks, if you like Thai noodles and you like spice, if you haven't eaten a plate of Pad Kee Mao with chicken at King of Thai #1, you haven't lived. I have tried it at the other King of Thais (Kings of Thai?) in the city, and some have been good but #1 on Clement between 7th and 8th does it at a level far above the rest. It is a simple dish, but they just do it exquisitely and pretty darn consistently. I should know, I have been going there and eating this same dish about an average of once a week for the last 12 years! Go, just go.
author: Adam S.

description:
So, this is my first ever Yelp review.  Unfortunately, I'm not going to be entirely entertaining or eloquent with it, as I'm tired and have had a long day and really need some sleep right now.  So without any fireworks or further ado:

We had the pineapple fried rice, the roasted red duck curry, the pad pri king (pork), these sort of stuffed pork and tofu appetizers (the name escapes me).  (Both entrees came with steamed rice as well.)

Portion sizes were just right. (Me and my friend are known to eat very hearty portions, and even we had just a slight bit left over after the meal was done).  I've dined at the other location on Clement and found this location's food to be far superior in the flavor department.

The price of the meal was standard.  Not expensive, but not particularly inexpensive (leaned closer to inexpensive though).  Totally worth every penny, given the lightning fast service and the quality of the dishes.

I'm a huge fan of Thai cuisine (when it's done well), but unfortunately not many of the Thai restaurants really deliver IMO, as I feel many of them lack a lot of the intricate flavors I like.  This restaurant though packed a lot of complex and thoughtful elements of taste into their food.  I was pleasantly surprised.   Their style almost reminded me of more of a Singaporean/Malaysian/Cambodian style of cooking, as compared to most of the other Thai restaurants I've dined at.   The pad pri king even went so far as to remind my friend and I, of some Korean dishes -- as it had a bit of the Gochujang flavor to it.  Given that we're both fans of spicy food, this worked in the dish's favor.   The duck curry was pretty standard duck curry -- pretty much the same everywhere and pretty hard to screw up.  My only criticism of this was that the duck was maybe a bit too mushy, and not firm enough.  The appetizer was savory.  The pineapple fried rice was quite impressive with a lot of strong flavors and textures -- raisins, cashews, pineapple of course, and the rice was really rich and robust tasting.

Service was friendly.  (Being the klutz that I am, I knocked down my water all over myself and the floor, and they totally cleaned it up the area promptly and were completely cool about it.)

The main criticism of the place is its size.  Luckily we went late at night, so it wasn't crowded and we got a seat.  But if you're there with a large group or when it's busy, it's a super cramped space and super small, so that might be troublesome.  But it just might be worth it for the food.  

Recommended.
author: Daniel P.

description: I've only had one dish there, but I get it frequently because it's so good that my tastebuds think they're having hallucinations.  Pineapple fried rice... Pineapple, chicken, rice, veggies, cucumber on the side. It's really good.  Also, very quick service, open late, and cheerfully & all-encompassing lavender color scheme.  Cash-only, however.
author: Evan H.

description: Good food and not much of a wait, therefore a decent alternative to Burma Super Star down the street. (There is a King of Thai near Union Square too and it is also good). The chicken satay was nice and the curries are very tasty. Wait staff is friendly and efficient. The prices are quite reasonable. Also, if you like purple, this is your place... if you've been there, you know what I mean.
author: Caitlin H.

description:
the shit! 
just read below... 
all the people that dont like it...
go back to the marina you yuppies
author: Angelo M.

description: This one or king of thai 2 just down the block.  Same owners, Cheap....great.  Then buy a book at green apple afterwards
author: Tim T.

description:
King of Thai is like climbing into comfy pajamas after getting out of a hot bath.  Not that you feel squeaky clean, but that you feel comfortable and satiated.  
This is my late night munchie fix (they're open until 1!).  That being said, I think their lunch time kitchen crew might have a bit more game.  
They aren't trying to be fancy but everyone who works there is wonderful and friendly.  I also feel very safe in a restaurant with an open kitchen.  They clearly have nothing to hide.
I really, really love this place and thank Supatra from the bottom of my heart for introducing me (hello!  Her name is Supatra, she obviously knows what's up).
Only other thing I should mention is that while I've tried bites of most of the dishes on the menu, I can't bring myself to order anything but the Pad Kee Mao with chicken.  So maybe I should be saying that I give the Pad Kee Mao five stars?
Why branch out when it brings me such exquisite pleasure?
author: Amanda S.

description:
i ve been to all of the king of thai's i didnt know they were all connected. parking really depends on which one you go to. service is ok its not the best. 

the food is good but i usually get the number 32 its fried rice with BBQ pork and chinese sausage. with some fish sauce its really good. the portions are real good. definitely a place to try if you havent tried it yet.
author: Nicholas Y.

description: Decently priced, opened late, no wait, fast service, almost instant food. Don't get the green curry here, it's not as good as it could be (too sweet, temperature of it wasn't hot).  Thick rice noodle dish was good (Pad See Iew?) as is the chicken with eggplant.  Good as a fast food thai option.
author: Kari L.

description: You can't go wrong with number 4 on the menu - the Guray Tiew Ruer Ruam (beef noodles).  It's my favorite.  Hits the spot every single time!
author: Mick S.

description: Great place when hungry late at night. Nothing feels great, but some good ol' pad thai after a few beers at the bars.
author: Sonlay V.

description: The original King of Thai.  It's super tiny, with maybe 10 tables.  There's never too many people in there, but the food is decent.  The service is really quick and they don't mind when you bring a 3 year old who is super nosy and keeps asking everyone why they are going to the bathroom.
author: Kris L.

description: Picked up a to go order of duck noodle soup and pumpkin curry.  The food was tasty, spicy and prepared within 5 minutes. They even gave me a cup of tea while I waited for my order.  I'll be back!
author: She-Ra ..

description: There is so much King of Thai's in the city! I wrote the wrong review for the wrong restaurant! I only ordered here once, the food came quick, the kitchen was in the front of the shop and I love looking at people cooking. The negative was that I saw a cockroach by the stove area, it was on the wall, I think this small shop should get a make over since it does look kind of old, I am sure the person who owns it doesn't mind paying for it because I am sure they make a whole lot of money with all of these King of Thai restaurants in SF.
author: Janet Z.

description: The old standby for a cheap, hearty, delicious meal that's in the neighborhood.  Late at night, when you want some yummy food and want to keep the buzz on, bring in a forty, order some pumpkin curry, and soak it in.
author: Mariss D.

description: I've eaten here more than I'd like to admit.  It's the only (somewhat clean and not scary) restaurant on Clement open past 11.  The food is always the same... it's just okay.  I guess there is just something missing in King of Thai's food... it seems rather soul less and plain.. it's just something to put in my stomach when I'm hungry.  Cheap, filling, and consistent... maybe that's some people's definition of good food... but not mine.
author: Stacy S.

description: 4 stars for good value and delicious taste. Try the #5 on a cold day
author: B H.

description: on point drinking grub. they actually understand english and have you drink free tea.
author: aidan m.

description: Simply, great cheap food with decent service in a non assuming location.  I used to go here on my way back home from work.  Top cheap eats in the City.
author: Ricky P.

description: What a great place to have a simple and nice Thai food for a very affordable price.  # 17 with Beef is my favorite.  I was at this restaurant 10 years ago when I visited the Bay Area for the first time and I really enjoyed their food.  10 years later, I visited the same place last week and #17 tasted as good as 10 years ago when I tasted it for the first time.  I really recommend this restaurant to anyone who like Thai food.  You won't be disappointed.
author: Charles K.

description: I go to King of Thai whenever I want a good, cheap meal.  Their noodles are excellent, and their rice is fantastic.  And, the cost is low.  What more can I say?
author: Raphael R.

description: The best for cheap and fast Thai food!
author: Vicky B.

description: King of Thai Noodle house is just ok.  The best thing about KTNH is that it opens late and the dishes comes out amazingly fast.  I think our order once came out in less than 5 mins.  I don't now if this is good or bad.  The menu is pretty good, plenty of dishes to choose from.  But I do have to say, uninspired food yields uninspired reviews.
author: Rick K.

description: It's alright. Maybe I'm not too big on Thai food, but the food isn't super good nor is it bad. Nice place for late night too.
author: Elaine H.

description: Maybe the most authentic of all the King of Thai chain, the snow fungus salad is cool, and sure to gross out less adventurous companions. For the meek, the Pad Thai is very good too.
author: Stellah D.

description: Decent food, horrible service. Only reason I'd come here is if you're done going out and need a decent place to eat at 1 AM. Be careful though, if you go in around closing time the waitresses get very snappy and mean. I wouldn't recommend this place based on bad service and cleaniness alone.
author: Anderson L.

description: Always consistent and lots of locations, especially in the Richmond. Their yum recipes are tangier than most places and you can't go wrong with the curry. And they are open late which is awesome
author: Jon S.

description: Love it. The late hours and the delicious food are some of my favorite things. First time I wandered in it was just kind of random, the second and third it was a refuge from drinking, starvation, and the cold. I thoroughly enjoyed the Pad Kee Mow and whatever the number 33 is as it is my friends favorite number we tried it and found it to be excellent. The service is fast which is good as the place isn't that large. I'm afraid I'll start rambling which would dilute my point and that this place is good.
author: Don L.

description:
King of Thai is a noodle house in spite of the name.  That's it, a noodle house.  It isn't gourmet.  This isn't the best Thai food available, but it's reasonable, served quickly, and good.

It's good enough to go back time after time.  I like the noodle soups.  I can't say that I've had a bad one.  The pad Thai is good, not great.  The shrimp is slightly overcooked, the dish is a little oversalted, but it's not--as in many Thai restaurants--floating in a puddle of grease.  The noodles are still noodles, not a quivering mass of rice gelatin.  And the sauce is really good in spite of the saltiness.

The service is always friendly.  The people greet you coming in and say goodbye as you leave.

It is cash only, which seems anachronistic in today's San Francisco, but a lot of the small ethnic restaurants seem to cling to the cash-only philosophy.
author: Richard C.

description: Other than IHOP....this is a great place for a late night run. The purple throws me off sometimes but that doesn't discourage me from the great food that you serve. I like deep fried, crunchy and peanutty. It irks me that you only take cash....arg....I had to run around for an hour looking for an atm once (at the other down town branch). I don't recall thai food tasting quite like theirs....in bangkok it was simply more intense....you know what I'm talking about? But since I'm not there and most places are closed when I'm done drinking I'm kind out of options...with that in mind this is a great place to go to. The staff seem to me at least to always be chipper. That's nice if not sometimes odd....when I've been drinking I don't think it's natural for people to be more chippy than me without drinking. lmao
author: John-Michael C.

description: When you need to stuff your gullet for cheap and it's late the King is the place to go. I can't say much for the decor but the servings are really large - very big.
author: Colin S.

description: This is more of a fast food Thai place with multiple locations in SF. I ordered a pad see ew here to go and they made it in about 5 minutes. Now that's fast. Their prices are cheap and you get good food. They stay open until 2 AM. Their other location on Clement (near 4th st) which is bigger isn't as good as this one.
author: Armstrong B.

description: This place is good when you are drunk.  I would not come here for a normal meal.  The food is pretty good, but then again I am always drunk from partying when I come here.  Duck fried rice every time.  It's open really late.
author: Christopher D.

description: The food is always delicious and the service is fast. I got food to go and they were speedy!
author: Sonya S.

description: this place is full of tasty and delicious thai food for really great prices!  this is our default go to place for dinner delivery because it never disappoints!  i am crazy about red curry, and king of thai makes it GOOD, so that is usually my dish of choice.  but i have tried a variety of other food there, including their pad see lew and pad thai and pineapple fried rice.  all amazing, all for about 7ish dollars each.  the dishes are consistently and reliably good, there's nothing more i can ask for.
author: Irene W.

description: Don't eat here when you are too drunk on a late night or else you'll leave stuff like your louis vuitton wallet (with SS card) behind, which the waiter will indeed steal. And when you call up the next day, they will tell you that he's gone back to Thailand. Bastard! (I miss you Louis)
author: Angel S.

description:
goood and CHEAP :) 

pad thai, sweet and sour shrimp, and uhh i dont remember the last name, but it was with chinese sausage and pork, with a thai sauce over rice,  that was 23$ and totally filled me & my boyfriend up. btw, it was 9pm and we both had not eaten since 8am. service is so-so. but hey, with cheap eats, who cares?

its just parking is a BITCH!
author: Coco C.

description: Tasty fried rice, some serious mystery meat in the beef noodle soup with beef stew, and won ton soup my other half enjoyed thoroughly.  Plus there was a ridiculously cute kid at the table next to us.  Low prices and big tables.  It looked like a lot of people were doing take-out.  And a large menu.  Definitely authentic Thai, based on both the menus, the staff, and the Thai handwriting on our receipt.  We like it.
author: Walter K.

description: Love the food and love the prices.  Definitely the best place to go in the neighborhood for a quick dinner on a Sunday or Monday night.  Disappointed with their take-out though - they never answer the phone, and when I go in person I have to wait forever and they sometimes completely ignore me until I get bored and decide to go somewhere else.  Takeout portions are small too.  So unless you're going to eat in, better to get it from the one near 5th.
author: Tali B.

description: Order a rice plate and the ground pork was so salty. Just doesn't taste the same as before.
author: Dave C.

description: A delicious Pad Kee Mao, served with incredible speed.  These guys know their way around a kitchen.  Don't go here expecting beautiful presentation or elegant service.  However, for a quick Thai fix, it is not bad at all.
author: Richard N.

description: I've been coming here for more than five years and love the affordable Thai dishes. It's a shame the prices have gone up in the last couple of years, but that's life I suppose. Some of my favorites are the fried chicken Thai fried rice, duck fried rice and the fried banana with coconut ice cream dessert. To die for...I always play a game when I eat here to time the food. Once it came out in three minutes flat. That's my kind of place.
author: Mel E.

description: Don't be fooled by the tacky purple decor...much like its sister restaurant in Union Square, this cash-only establishment has some AMAZING food without breaking your wallet.  My favorites are the green curry with chicken, the spring rolls, the see ew (sp?) noodles with chicken, and this fried chicken over fried rice with the hot and sour sauce.  Finish off with some mango sticky rice for dessert and you will be in heaven.
author: Lisa L.

description: I have never come here again ever since I saw one of the employees do the grossest thing.  He was trying to clear out one of the tables of some previous customers.  There were duck bones left there so the guy used his bare hands to grab them and sweep them into the plastic tub where cleared dishes go.  After he cleared the table, he went to get this old, dirty, greasy towel that had obviously wiped so many other tables before and started wiping the table with it.  Then without even washing his hands after that, proceeded to take a bag of those lovely rice noodles that get served with your meal, and started grabbing them with his hands and rubbing them together so as to free up the noodles so they don't clump.  I'd rather their kitchen be behind doors so I don't see stuff like that.  Ignorance is bliss.
author: Kit E.

description: Great cheap thai food. Fast service. A bit hole-in-the-wall-ish, but a bargain.
author: Joy C.

description: The best of the king of thai resturants. Service here is always wondeful and food quality is always great. Can be packed at times, but generally not to difficult to get seats. Parking here is always easy even though it's on clement compared to the other noodle house.
author: David M.

description: I think I give it a 4 star since I have been going here since college.  I always order the pad see wah w/ pork and it has been great for 6 yrs. plus. The satay's have been better, but the green curry has always been.  It also never been an expensive dinner place which is great and they are open till 2 am if memory serves.  I am a fan, the wait staff has been the same for yrs and is always SUPER nice.  Go you will not be disappointed.
author: Nicole F.

description: The Thai food was decent, I've had better for sure. I had the Pad Thai and added chicken with it.  My friend had the Guay Tiew Ruer Ruam and it was very bland. Decent food and decent service, I just liked it because it was the only spot that was open super late after we got out of Rohan and plus I was a bit tipsy. 3 stars for super greasy Thai food, woohoo!
author: Steve N.

description:
If I feel like having soup or garlic food---I usually go here and order their spicy soup and beef garlic entree. The people are nice and service is good. 

I think they have another location in DT (corner side of SF Shopping Center b/w Market and 5th). I like that location as well b/c they have a live music band.
author: JM M.

description: I always get to-go here and it's so interesting to watch them cook it.  I always get Pad See Lew which resembles the Chinese Cuisine : Beef Chow Fun.  Haha. But anyway, one dude cooks the noodles, then the next thing I know he passes the wok to another dude and he starts to add everything into it.  It's quite an interesting process.  Finally, the dude pours my food into a togo box and one of those weird Thai chicks hands me my food.  & I walk back to work and enjoy my hot steamy meal.  Yum.
author: Tina L.

description: Absolutely delicious! You can't go wrong with the pad thai or any of the curries. The curries are really tasty and flavorful; goes well with rice. Pad Thai noodles are also well seasoned and a perfect fit for me and my friends who were hungry after movies and shopping.
author: Karina C.

description:
eh, maybe because i live here now and i don't appreciate them as much but i think it's gone downhill a bit.  lately, it seems my noodles are always soggy and stuck together (i order #17).

sigh...i hate to do this, but i'm just giving it an "A-OK".
author: Sally T.

description: Oily Oily Oily... put it this way, I brought my friend here and she broke out in hives after eating the shrimp. Be prepared for some serious MSG if you are going to eat here.
author: Mike L.

description: Weird that people don't like this place. I could see why you may don't want to actually sit and eat in the restaurant itself because I think it's so small. So, I've always got take outs. The Pad Thais is good, pad seuw is good, and more stuff that I have ordered have never disappointed me. Try take out, maybe you can enjoy the food better.
author: Daisy S.

description:
I hate myself every time I stray from King of Thai in my thai delivery pursuits. I always get burned (see Visit Thai). 

So much food, so CONSISTENTLY delicious, and so damn cheap. I love you K of T. I was foolish to think anyone else could please me the way you do. I'll never take you for granted again, giant-quart-of-creamy-perfectly-flavored-red curry.
author: Annie L.

description: I don't really like this King of Thai Noodle. I usually order the #17. Pad Kee Maow, I think is the name. I never ate here before, only order to go but one o the waitress definitely didn't seem like she need a job. When I went in to pick up my food, she was busy on the cell phone chatting the day away...not the service I needed when I was starving after a long day at school. The dish didn't taste good....pretty bland, no spice. I wold never come back here again...
author: Audrey M.

description:
as soon as i arrived in san francisco after 10 hours in the airplane and the airport, my friend took me to this place.  i used to come here (not this location but in taravel) everytime i visit san fran.  i didn't realize this friend knew this place but i guess almost everybody knows the king of thai so when he mentioned to go to this place i didn't complaint.  

i had a hot noodle soup (#4) and it was soooo good.  it's a little bit sweeter than i would like my soup but it was so good.  this place is definitely better than the one in taravel.
author: donald c.

description: King of Thigh...mark my words, will be the next Starbucks.  All starting from this humble locale.  Service is quick, responsive, and the food comes out oh so fast.  Yes, not the best thai food, but like other reviewers have said, it's open late.
author: Al K.

description: Been here so many countless times...one of the best thai rest i've been to....Well i only like the Thai on Clement and 4th ? i think.   All the other ones suck.  and the first one, the hole in the cubby....its really really really not sanitary...couple times i've seen roaches crawling on walls and you kind of wonder what's going on with the insect stuff.  Anywways...cheap and good food.  would highly recommend the one on Clement next to Genkis...
author: Shirley H.

description:
i've been going to king of thai at both locations on clement for over 8+ years.  its very good, low priced thai food which i can always count on.

nothing like a hot bowl of their noodles on a rainy winter san francsico night.

i've tried over half of their menu and have my tried and true favorites.

their staff is always friendly and attentive in both locations on clement.

on most nights my partner and i can walk there, get two entrees, two cans of pop and leave with a 20 spot on the table that covers dinner and 15% percent.

i love king of thai, its a weekly standby with consistantly good and tasty food, and  an affordable favorite.

:-D
author: Patrick M.

description: i love thai food! i would have thai once a week in LA, but the last time i was here, i discovered a piece of raw chicken fat in my salad! I am a vegetarian, if i found a piece of cooked chicken in my salad-- i would not mind as much, BUT this was a a piece of raw fat...disgusting!.  the tom yum was good, and cheap.
author: Hana ..

description: King of Thai is awesome, the food is great and it's super cheap for big portions that can last for a few meals and they always have seating at lunch.  Highly recomended.
author: Elizabeth D.

description: I LOVE the food at KOT.  #15,17,18 is so good.  Or the Tom Yum Gai with rice noodles....or Pumpkin curry....oh I want KOT now!  I love the purple decor and I love how my order is actually written in Thai.  Makes it more authentic.  Sizable portion and reasonable prices, my tummy and wallet are both very happy.
author: Chrisy C.

description: Two and half -- It's no Osha.  The line at Burma Superstar was too long so we went here. I had to ask for the table to be wiped off, everyone at the table agreed that the pumpkin curry needed to be hotter, the crunchy noodle dish and tom kha gai was average, and the shrimp in garlic sauce was subpar.
author: Adam Z.

description:
This location is FABULOUS if you are getting take out, but not so fabulous if you're eating in...by yourself...at the table in the back by the restroom...

Need I say more?
author: Christine H.

description: I love how late this place is open and how reliable and cheap everything is. It's my go to Thai spot in the hood(and I live in the Richmond so you KNOW theres some legit competition). I usually go for that thing that involves lightly battered chicken over fried rice. Always super satisfying and seems to be one of their better dishes. The duck fried rice is on the salty side....but you know, it IS duck fried rice. My boyfriend gets the Pad Thai wherever we go and this place is one of his favorites. I'd imagine eating in here alone would be pretty depressing but whenever I go it's with a group of friends late at night so the decor doesn't really bother me. Plus their delivery is super fast so why bother even getting out of your pajamas?
author: Nadia P.

description: My wife and I drive here late night for some super spicy noodles.  I have been coming here for so many years.  Highly recommended.  Tip; try the Tom Kha soup, you will be surprised.
author: A K.

description:
Deliciously fresh and tantalizing. Another easy-to-miss location on Clement St. Sometimes the aroma of Fresh Thai food jumping out at you is the only way you know you're walking past this location. I've been living so close to this place for so long and have just recently started to go.
When you enter the location you can see all the fresh ingredients over the glass screen (a la Subway) and the cooks enjoying their job. There is not much room for seating so it's always better if you order the food to go.
I ordered flat noodles with beef yesterday and it was the most delicious thing I've eat all week! The time before that I ordered the duck/rice. The sauce was exceptional and everything tasted so fresh. Both times I placed the order at the counter got it to go and it took less than 10 minutes. 
The price is very reasonable for the food and the hours are great for those night owls amongst us! The only thing is I wish the portion sizes were a little bit bigger. The food is so good it always leaves me wanting more.
author: Wilson S.

description: Yummieiieie, knocked off the other star cause service could use improvement.
author: Syonora A.

description: Very good food, but it's a really tiny place.  There were some unique dishes that I had not seen elsewhere, and it was pretty damn cheap too.  It was cash only though.
author: Ryan B.

description: King of Thai Noodle on Clement rocks my world late at night!  With only 10 dollars left  in your pocket they can fill your belly and make your taste buds feel comforted...  They have these spicy noodles that always sound like a good idea at the time, but the next morning your stomach makes some weird noises.  At first I thought this was just me, but after discussing it with my friends we realized it's a fact.  You'd think after this realization that we would order something else, but last night we went and we all ordered the same spicy noodles, its worth it.
author: Cassie L.

description: Not the greatest thai restaurant, but pretty good for a day to day thing. bad service, but cheap good thai food.
author: Simmy S.

description: I love this place. Its a hole in the wall type of restaurant, so dont expect too much from their customer service or ambience, but food is great.
author: Kaitlyn B.

description: My favorite thai noodle place.... My thai friend took me there, telling me that this place offers an "authentic thai noodle" in 1995.  I've been a royal customer.  Sometimes went to the one on Taravel (don't see here anymore... closed??) or the one near VA (Closed...).  Somehow I didn't like the other one on Clement (No.2).
author: Mike M.

description: This is probably one of the BEST Thai restaurants I've eaten at. Good service, always available seating and open pretty late. Their portions are very nice and the prices are very affordable. I love their curries and this one dish I forgot about the name which you can choose what meat and has chow fun noodles and chinese brocolli with a nice sweet and tangy soy sauce kind of glaze. Most of all, their Phad Thai is GODLY, haha! I highly recommend this place!
author: Sean E.

description:
thai is my favorite food in the world.  as such, i am super picky.  like... REALLY picky when it comes to my thai food.  since i had curry the previous day, i went with my buddy's recommendation of #16, which was some conglomeration of pretty much every ingredient they could find in the kitchen (memory says flat noodles, onions, mushrooms, peppers, squid, shrimp, imitation crab, sprouts, green onions) with a bunch of sauce poured on top.  meh.  i probably ordered the wrong thing, but my friends' ravings of this place certainly were not justified that day.  filling? yes.  satisfying? maybe.  another visit? prolly not.  i guess if it's late and i need a thai fix, i may visit another location.  i'll be weary though...

as an afterthought, the #16 didn't translate very well to a #2 either...
author: Jon Y.

description: Good place to go after a night of drinking.  Better than IHOP, or the places in Chinatown.  Cheap as hell too.  Not a fan of the soups, but fried rice is always the shizzle.
author: A L.

description:
KOT Rocks. My favorites are the pad prik King and the Tom Kha Gai.  The last time I got the yellow curry, it had way too many onions and they were in various states of being cooked... but this place is really consistant. I often go there late night and I am consistantly amazed at how quickly I have a hot plate of delicious food in front of me. Friendly - Fast - Yummy.

(I would likely give it another full star if it weren't for the sometimes loud/bad/annoying karaoke sounding music that they play.  )
author: Joshua H.

description: I am a huge yellow curry fan and this place had really tasty curry.  I highly recommend.
author: Alex E.

description: I used to love this place until I heard they have MSG in there food.   It's still  tastes good and now a days a lot foods have MSG.  Since I heard this I have stayed away.  I could be wrong about my my 411 but thats the word on the street.
author: Robert M.

description:
i love this place. even though there are 845454 KOT around SF, this one is great. the service is quick and the food is pretty good for thai fast food. 
i enjoy the number 2 beef ball soup and thai spicy som tum. plus theres a TV just in case you have a boring person with you. the bathroom is really small and right next to the tables..if that bothers you. CASH ONLY but theres a BOFA across the st.
author: andree t.

description:
My husband says that if he were about to be executed, he'd request #17, extra spicy, for his last meal. I think this is crazy -- I mean, we're talking $7 pad kee mao here -- but I see his point. My pad-kee-mao-crazy spouse has tried this dish all over the city, even at four other King of Thai locations. But no one combines wide flat noodles, ground duck, basil, green beans, spice and sauce to such perfection. We've been eating #17 here since ... well, I guess since it was #18.  

The duck noodle soup is also super tasty. The tom yum kai, the larb salad, and the curries are also solid, though you can good versions of these dishes everywhere. Also, don't get this location confused with the large King of Thai #2 location between 4th and 5th, which serves lesser #17.
author: Midori S.

description: Good thai noodle soup.  Spicy beef soup and add extra chili..and...yummmmmyyyyyy.....Service is always fast and the soup is always GOOD.....
author: Pikachu P.

description: I love everything they cook. My favorite dish is the yellow curry. They have a yummy hot tea. The service is great. They really deserve five stars!
author: M J.

description:
For a Thai restaurant chain the food is good.  I've had the pad see ew, beef noddle soup, pad prik khing, beef salad, and duck fried rice.  I like everything I've eatten here so far.  It's fast with service too.  Only waited 8mins for food.  Everytime I phoned in an order, it's done in less then 10mins.  It is true that the food is greasy and salty, but asian food consist of this

The king of Thai on Taraval gives you free thai ice tea or coffee with a order.  That's pretty nice of them.  Anyways, would recommend this chained thai restaurant.
author: K T.

description: The best King of Thai Noodle House in SF, I think. The rest are mediocre.
author: Robert S.

description: King of Thai is like the sun...  everyday I know it's going to be there.. sometimes it soaks my skin with warmth and love, and sometimes it gets in my eyes when I'm trying to drive... but it's always consistently there, no surprises..
author: alan j.

description: This is a tiny hole in a wall place but the food is consistent and very tasty.  My favorite Thai place in the city and peninsula.  Tom Yum soup is super spicy and sour the way it should be and chock full off tasty morsels.  Service is always quick.
author: E C.

description:
So far, this is my favorite place for cheap Thai food in SF.  I get lunch here at least once a week -- usually the red curry with duck, but nearly everything I've had I was happy with given the price.  Service is fast and polite.

Their Pad Thai is not my favorite -- but I'm not sure if that's a matter of the style of how it's made, or an actual quality issue.  

In my opinion, this location is subtly better than the #2 location a few blocks east on Clement.  Even though it's smaller, I never seem to need to wait to be seated -- I suppose it gets a lot more carry-out business at lunchtime.
author: Michael M.

description:
Food is good but this place is small and the only seat left was near the bathroom.  


their noodles in broth is great on a very very cold day.
author: kenny l.

description: The food it consistently the same: fresh, quick, delicious and very reasonably priced. Service is immediate and responsive most all the time except when totally full. They will even customize some of the dishes if you ask. Not a place to go if you don't use cash and/or if you want to have a quiet and intimate dinner. However if you need your food fast and don't mind people around its the one to try on Clement. This one btw - has a lot better service than the one near Union Square. That one used to be my favorite... but now they make you sit at small tables when there are only two people - I need a large table for all the food I order...
author: Dave P.

description: I used to love this place, and then recently the wait staff has become very rude and mean, especially if you are not of the right skin color/ethnicity.   Restaurants are hitting hard times these days, and for someone to be picky about their clientele, it's just not good.  Just last week I ordered many items to go.  The chicken satay was skimpy, and very expensive for what you got.  Four small slices of skewered chicken for $6.95??  Really!  Then I wanted a few of the deep fried won ton skins -- 4 for a $1 -- you gotta be kidding me!  The food is OK, but not great enough to warrant these prices for the amount you get.  No thanks . . . I won't be going back there.  Plenty of other good Thai restaurants that don't mind taking my cash and giving me good food and value for my money.
author: Jacqueline D.

description: The prices at King of Thai are right, and they're open late, which is an added bonus.  However, I have found that over the past year or so their dishes seem saltier to me.  I don't know if the cook has been replaced or what.  Not bad overall though.
author: Methanie D.

description: Pad Kee Mao.  The best Thai noodles for your dollar in the city, fast service and sometimes Thai pop music videos.
author: Britton R.

description:
I only come here to eat the Thai food, because their ingredients are flavorful. But the one thing that I hate the most about coming to any of the King of Thais is that the service is HORRIBLE.  It doesn't matter which location you go to, the service is the same at every location.  I can only come here when I'm in a good mood because the waiters/waitresses always look  super depressed. On top of that, they are rude and they give a lot of attitude.  I get extremely irritated when they get your order wrong and you polietly correct them, they snap back at you with a lot of attitude like it was your fault that they gave you the duck noodle soup when you ordered the pad thai.  The waiters/waitresses also have a bad habit of muttering phrases under their breaths in a different language as they walk away from your table.
One time, I asked the waitress if we could get our Thai iced teas, she looked at me, rolled her eyes and walked back to the kitchen to get us our drinks. I would recommend this place  to you if you don't mind being treated like crap. Like I said, I only can handle their service when I am in a good mood.
author: J W.

description: Much better Thai food elsewhere, plus it's overpriced.
author: CC H.

description: Decent Thai restaurant.  I've tried quite a few dishes here and most of them are decent.  My favorite is definitely the fried chicken fried rice.  Their roast duck fried rice is OK too.  I've also tried yellow curry chicken, pad thai, roast duck w/rice, fish cakes, chicken/shrimp with pan fried rice noodles, and others I can't seem to remember.  They are decent for easy meals.  Service is average, but you can't expect much from a semi-chain type of restaurant.
author: Tom S.

description:
this restaurant is like the proverbial picture of your grandkids in your wallet.....somehow, no matter how many times you've said it all already, you just can't shut up about how awesome it is.

service:  service in the restaurant is good, but that's not what this place is about.  this is the King of Thai which DELIVERS.  and by that, i mean they arrive two minutes before you place your order.  truthfully, i timed it once, and they were at my house five minutes after i hung up the phone.  i hadn't even found my wallet yet.

food:  ohgoddgimmenowplz.  #1 & #6 are my dream comfort noodlesoups.  i've heard weird things about some of the soups that don't have sliced meats... but luckily i don't eat weird meats to begin with.  the pad see ew and pad kee mao are where my real weakness lies, however.  one drunken night after a fit of pad see ew, it featured prominently in my dreams....and it's stayed there ever since.  i actually get mouthwatering-instacravings for this stuff.  it's inspired myself & my boyfriend to chant "NOODLENOODLENOODLES!" in public.  during the day.

price:  whenever i over-order enough delivery to last two people two full days......it costs 25$ with tip.
author: Mishka F.

description:
I like the staff's fancy purple uniforms
Pad Thai here is awesome.
I crave their pad thai every other day.
author: Lynn T.

description:
I've been to three of these so far, one in the sunset and both on clement street. By far this one is my favorite, the servings of food are always bigger here than they are at either of the other locations. The food is consistently great and it's a perfect place for Sunday afternoon hangovers. 

Pad Se Lew (I think) is what I get all the time, stir fried noodles with (meat of your choice) is fantastic. Always fills me up right! 

Keep up the good work KoTN - you guys rock!
author: John K.

description: This place has great noodle and rice dishes for a decent price... sometimes the ground beef is a little scary, but most of the time I am very pleased!
author: J-man K.

description:
Most dishes (save Gai Satay) are a far cry from what authentic Thai food tastes like..

I know, I know. This isn't exactly "Thailand". But they could at least do a better job of presenting it.. Maybe have the colors of the dish look the same.

It's alright for a drunken late night, if Nizario's is for some reason closed.
author: Mic F.

description: oh boy...i keep going to this location hoping it will get better, because i used to be a big fan, but it hasn't been great.  the flavors are still good, but the protein portions (meat and tofu) are really sad, like sugar-cube sized tofu.  hope they can turn it around!
author: t L.

description: i always come to king of thai for their duck fried rice with chinese sausage! soooo goood! :)
author: linda L.

description: great food! its the real deal, very authentic. great food, great price. its not gourmet food or quality but your everyday typical food.
author: Susie S.

description: after a night of drinking at the 540 club, the plough and the stars, the rockit room or any other bar around the area, this is a tasty place to fulfill the late night  munchies.
author: Sheri N.

description: I didn't expect much given the fast food type of atmosphere from this place.  It was not the best Thai I've ever had but the food was edible and balanced in flavor while being reasonably affordable.  I had the pad see ew, green curry, pineapple fried rice, and chicken satay.  I would not order the fried rice again (so boring in flavor) but the satay was better than expected (moist and tasty accompanying sauce).  Curry was spicy but good and the pad see ew was tasty but typical.  I would return if I was in a rush, in the neighborhood, and craving Thai.
author: sasaw A.

description: cheap, good, open late...and i saw a lesbian couple quarrel...and believe it or not...they were kinda cute. dinner and a show...what do u know?!
author: dae m.

description: blech! greasy food made with cheap ingredients.
author: Mitsi M.

description: great place if you're out late and looking for something authentic and inexpensive.  one of the dishes i ordered was the glass noodle with fish sauce.  honestly, it wasn't that good, but all the other dishes we ordered was worth it.  i'd go back there again.
author: Tawny A.

description: ever since they remodeled the service has been bad at the one on clement and 5th, the lady was so rude to me last time i was there that i had to write a bad review, food isnt that great either.
author: Jonathan S.

description: After a long day of apt hunting lunch was late at 1:30 pm.  We walked in (Oooo just saw Zachary B.'s posting that this place is open til 2 am. NICE) and were immediately seated and served.  I still think my favorite Thai place is Vieng Thai in Houston, TX, but I'm sure I'll be adding to that list once I'm an all-out SF transplant.  I had the gang karee, which is the yellow curry with chicken, onion and potatoes.  It was served with sweet and sour pickled cucumber salad.  Pickled cucumber, always sounds funny. Anyways! I thought maybe the dish could've used more color and maybe more vegetables, but that's probably how generations of Thai people have cooked it and who am I as a Chinese person to judge??? The dish was plentiful and flavorful and it definitely fueled my next 4 hours of apt searching.  Most dishes if I remember correctly were around $10.50 I believe. I'll definitely go back for more in the future.
author: Jen T.

description: Super cheap, super spicy and good, open way late. What more could a broke, spice freak, insomniac like myself want?
author: Jonathan M.

description: Good OG Hole in the Wall that's been around for a long time.  I'm Thai American, so I know Thai food fairly well.  This is one of the better spots in sf in my opinion.  Lots more flavor than many other places that just are too bland or over sweetened.  Def. not as good as Thailand, but pretty good nonetheless.  And open late.  If you want to keep it safe, stick with the Pad See Eew, one of the Fried Rice dishes (I like duck fried rice for the flavor), Pad Ka Pao (if you like Basil), or Pad Thai.  Ask for a fried egg on top of your fried rice or Pad Ka Pao.  Adds that extra somethin somethin.
author: Dirty S.

description: after a long night of being inebriated one of the best places to scarf down some garlic and chicken over rice and some thai hot and sour soup................
author: Jay G.

description: Consistently good Thai food.  I usually have the Chicken Ka Prow (minced chicken with spicy basil sauce) over rice with a fried egg.  You can't go wrong ordering from here, and the prices are very reasonable.
author: nick t.

description:
so i usually go here during the week sometime, in my sweatpants around midnight with my male doppelganger. okay we don't really look alike, but whatever. the ONLY reason i chose to give 4 stars is because i-- err, WE are obsessed with one glorious bowl of soup....the tom yum gai! oh so yum...i could eat this everyday. even on hot, smoldering days, i'll do it (don't tempt me!) i love it so much, i even thought about how i could create a tom yum gai waterfall at my house, or hire a full time tom yum gai cook at my disposal. (weird, i know)
now a few things...i'm a MAJOR germaphobe so normally i wouldn't eat at an establishment like this without a full body condom. but for some strange reason- lets call it a strange working of the cosmos, i MUST have the tom yum gai (with flat rice noodles, and fried garlic on the side)...i turn my head when the cooks enter and exit the not so pristine bathroom wearing the same gloves they use to cook.
and the only slightly embarrassing thing about my obsession is that the cooks and the waiters know who we are and scream out "TOM YUM GAIII!" everytime we walk in the door.
KOT makes it with a lot of MSG, because i find myself drinking a gallon of water thereafter, so I'll recommend a better place for healthier TYG later, but still....i don't care. love is blind! KOT tom yum gai, you had me at hello...
author: Lori J.

description: one of my favorite little neighborhood spots. i cant help but go there at least once a week. its also nice that they're open till 2AM (more like 1:20-40AM). i wouldnt go as far as to say that it's the best thai food i've ever had but its always a good meal. plus everyone i've ever taken there has left satisfied.
author: Andrew D.

description: one of the most efficient places i've ever eaten at.  value-driven.  impressive speedy service, esp for a place by union square.  clean.  decent food and you'll be in and out in no time.  i usually get noodle soup.
author: Catherine H.

description: love you. i have always loved you. i wake up full of sweat in the night dreaming about you
author: shanti s.

description: pad thai was decent, felt that it could have had more flavor/spice.  Delivery was quick and friendly.  Cash only
author: Tyler S.

description: Although their menu is pretty basic (especially veggie dishes) their Pad See Yew is fantastic!  Usually room to bring a toddler and not fancy.
author: Dawn N.

description: You can't go wrong here. The prices are great, the serving sizes are huge (please don't make them smaller because I said this) and the food is super.
author: suz q.

description: i always order # 17 ( forget the name) pad kee mao? its like chow fun (wide rice noodles) stir fry with seafood (shrimp, squid, fish cake, imitation crab) with basil and sweet chili. yummm!
author: Linda L.

description: Of the 4 Thai places that are within 2 blocks of 8th and Clement, this is the one to go to.  Not fantastic ambiance, but the food is definitely the best.  You can generally pick something up there within 10 minutes of ordering, which is another nice benefit.
author: Larry M.

description: decently priced and it's open pretty late.  a few of these establishment around the city.  definitely try the YEN TA FOWL  or a can't miss for me.... thai crab fried rice.  :)  decor is purple....  why purple?  i always wondered about that.
author: jay c.

description: One of my favorite Thai places to eat. Opens really late and the prices are very reasonable. The only gripe about the place is that it is a bit small and the bathroom is tagged up and a bit questionable. I love the Pad Kee Mao here an my sister always enjoys the number 5 i think? the noodle soup I believe. The service here is either hit or miss too. Sometimes you will have a waitress that completely knows what they are doing and would constantly check like a Nazi if your water/tea needs refilling, while other times the waitress could not give a rat's ass about your dining experience ( If i was choking and nearly dying...that shotty waitress would probably not even strain her neck to turn around and save me-unless maybe I flash a few dollars...I'm not sure). If you dont mind gambling for service, this place is your place to go to for cheap, good, thai food.
author: Amanda Y.

description: Yummy late night treat.  Its my one and only late night meal on Clement St. And you wont break the bank.
author: Stephanie S.

description: Probably dumb of me to get a rice dish at a place that calls itself a noodle house.  I had the peanut-sauce chicken on rice, which was gluey and mediocre.  My colleagues had the pad-see-ew, which they said was good, but they are not as food centric as I am, so I can't say...
author: Andrea P.

description: This is not the kind of place I would walk into without a solid recommendation. There is nothing visually special about it, it is poorly decorated and  lit, noisy, crowded, etc. But the food is wonderful. When I go, I usually get the same thing over and over: a deep-fried breaded cutlet of chicken with basil fried rice (sorry, cannot recall the Thai name). But my friends have tried many other dishes and they all raved.
author: Jose C.

description: This place is perfect for lunch! Small dining area, but the service is very fast. Most dishes come a la carte, so sharing family style may be difficult. Food is flavorful and authentic. Portions are somewhat small, but the prices are even smaller!
author: M. W.

description: SOLID SPOT.  Prices are reasonable and the food is awesome.  So far had the pad see ew, fried sweet and sour chicken over fried rice (the rice is surprisingly not greasy) and the plain old chicken noodle soup (hangover cure).  Citrus club just got bumped.
author: Mike Honcho H.

description: i came here during my high school years. my friends and i would usually do the phone order and just pick up, very convenient that way. i've never dine in here before because they look so small. the good thing is you get to sit in those stool kinna thing and watch them cook!
author: Valerie N.

description: bad service, rude servers, bad food. my crab fried rice tasted like white rice with a lot of msg and oil mixed in it with specks of crab meat. the pad thai tasted like jelly. my duck noodle soup had a strand of curly hair in it. the waitress told me to move when i was waiting for a table and stomped a chair leg on my foot and then said it was my fault for not moving. plus they only take cash here. definitely would not go back.
author: D M.

description: food comes fast, generously portioned, and with a cheap price tag.  fried chicken over fried rice !
author: Jay P.

description: I love two things at this place. The Pad Thai and the Tom Yum Noodle Soup. I love pad thai and they kinda taste different at different places, but nontheless, I like it here. The Tom Yum Noodle Soup.. I''ve had this at other places, but it tastes the best here.. maybe because i'm only  there when it's late on a friday night, right before they close.. after all the late night activities..
author: Mari K.

description: Free delivery!  But the prices are different than the menu that is here on yelp.   OH THE TRICKERY.  Food is pretty decent though.
author: Marcus B.

description:
fast fast fast! makes me wonder how they do it. 
i've had better but this is my first choice when it comes to local. 
favorite dishes: the papaya salad and the pad kee mao, good stuff
they also do a pretty mean thai iced tea. 
pretty good prices and they're nice. 
someone said they got really sick, i haven't had any problems for about two years now and i eat there maybe once or twice a month. hmmm, strange.
author: Sasha R.

description: Fast, cheap, and really hits the spot.  My go to lunch/dinner place when I was a poor college student.
author: Heidy M.

description: best pad thai i've had! when i come here it's usually late night, and i'm fulfilling my pad thai fix. my usual order= pad thai + thai iced tea. just lovely.
author: Je M.
